dition of  the  property  under  their  charge,  which  reports  shall  be  transmitted  by  the  Governor 
to  the  Legislature  at  the  time  of  making  the  annual  report,  as  provided  in  this  section.  It  shall 
be  the  duty  of  the  Secretary  to  estimate  the  surplus  money  growing  out  of  the  revenues  from 
said  wharfs,  over  and  above  the  requirements  of  the  first  four  subdivisions  of  section  three  of 
this  Act,  and  when  such  surplus  is  ascertained,  the  same  shall  be  set  apart  by  the  State  Treas- 
urer as  a  Sp(>cial  Fund,  to  be  called  the  "San  Francisco  Harbor  Protection  Fund,"  to  be  used 
exclusively  in  the  building  and  construction  of  such  sea  wall  along  the  line  of  the  water  front 
of  said  city  and  county  as  shall  hereafter,  upon  accurate  survey,  be  found  necessary  for  the  pro- 
tection and  security  of  the  liarbor  and  water  front  of  said  city  and  county. 

Sec.  14.  Upon  the  accumulation  of  the  sum  of  twenty-five  thousand  dollars  in  said  "  Har- 
bor Protection  Fund,"  the  Commissioners  shall  cause  a  survey  and  estimates  to  be  made  for  the 
construction  of  a  sea  wall,  and  tiic  expense  of  such  survey  and  the  costs  of  constructing  said 
sea  wall  shall  be  paid  out  of  the  "  Harbor  Protection  Fund."  Such  sea  wall  shall  be  constructed 
by  contract,  in  sections  of  not  more  than  two  blocks  in  one  contract,  and  all  contracts  for  that 
purpose  shall  be  made  in  accordance  with  the  provisions  of  section  nine  of  this  Act. 

Sec.  15.  In  the  event  of  the  death  or  resignation  of  either  of  the  Commissioners  elected 
under  this  Act,  the  Governor  shnll  fill  the  vacancy  by  appointment,  and  the  appointee  shall  hold 
the  office  until  the  next  general  or  municipal  election,  or  meeting  of  the  Legislature,  as  the  case 
may  be.  Any  person  so  appointed  to  fill  a  vacancy  in  the  Board  of  Commissioners  shall  give  a 
like  bond  and  subscribe  to  a  like  oath  as  those  required  of  Commissioners  elected  under  this 
Act,  before  he  receives  a  commission  from  the  Governor.  If  any  one  of  said  Commissioners,  or 
the  Secretary  of  the  Board,  shall  absent  himself  from  the  State  for  a  space  of  sixty  days,  he 
shall  be  deemed  to  have  vacated  the  office  held  under  this  Act,  and  the  Governor  shall  appoint 
his  successor,  who  shall  hold  the  office  until  the  next  general  or  municipal  election,  or  meeting 
of  the  liCgislature,  as  the  case  may  be,  at  which  time  his  successor  shall  be  elected,  and  hold  his 
office  for  the  balance  of  the  unexpired  term.  And  such  appointee  shall  give  a  like  bond  and 
subscribe  to  a  like  oath  as  those  required  of  his  predecessor. 

Sec.  16.  It  shall  be  and  is  hereby  made  the  duty  of  the  Attorney-General  of  the  State  to 
give  such  legal  advice  and  render  such  legal  services  as  may,  from  time  to  time,  be  required  of 
him  by  the  Commissioners,  in  connection  with  their  duties  under  this  Act. 

Sec.  17.     The  salary  of  each  Commissioner  shall  be  one  hundred  dollars  per  month.     The 


486 


SAN    FRANCISCO     DIRECTORY. 


salary  of  tho  Secretary  shall  be  two  Iiuiidrctl  dollars  per  nioiith.  Tlie  said  nalaries  shall  be  pay- 
able monthly,  out  of  any  moneys  collected  under  this  Act. 

Sec.  18.  No  person  shall  be  eligible  to  any  office  under  this  Act  unless  he  has  been  a  resi- 
dent and  citizen  of  this  State  at  least  two  years  next  prior  to  the  time  of  his  election  or  appoint- 
ment. 

Skc.  19.  Should  any  personal  injury  or  loss  of  property  occur  in  consequence  of  the  neglect 
of  the  lessees  to  keep  the  wharfs,  docks,  and  landing  places  in  good  repair,  the  party  receiving 
the  personal  injury  or  losing  the  property  may  proceed  against  the  said  lessees  in  any  Court  of 
competent  jurisdiction  ;  and  the  said  lessees  shall  be  responsible  on  the  bonds  given  to  the  Staie 
Harbor  Commissioners  for  the  faithful  performance  of  their  contract,  for  all  judgments  obtained 
against  them  for  losses  or  injuries  sustained  in  consequence  of  such  neglect. 

Sec.  20.  No  person  or  company  shall,  after  the  Commissioners  elected  under  this  Act  shall 
have  been  commissioned  as  herein  provided,  collect  any  tolls,  wharfage,  and  dockage,  upon  any 
portion  of  the  water  Iront  of  the  City  and  County  of  San  Francisco,  nor  shall  any  person  or 
persons  land  or  ship  any  goods,  wares,  or  merchandise,  or  other  thing,  upon  or  from  any  portion 
of  the  said  water  front  of  said  City  and  County  of  San  Francisco,  unless  authorized  so  to  do 
by  the  said  Commissioners,  excepting  such  persons  or  companies  as  may  hold  possession  of  some 
portion  of  the  property  described  in  this  Act  by  valid  leases.  Any  person  violating  or  offend- 
ing against  the  prohibition  in  this  section  contained  shall  be  deemed  guilty  of  a  misdemeanor, 
and  upon  conviction  thereof  in  any  Court  of  competent  jurisdiction,  shall  be  punished  by  a  fine 
not  exceeding  five  hundred  dollars,  or  by  imprisonment  in  the  County  Jail  of  the  City  and 
County  of  San  Francisco  not  exceeding  six  months,  or  by  both  such  fine  and  imprisonment. 

Sec.  21.  Whenever,  in  this  Act,  authority  is  given  to  dredge  docks,  repair  wharfs,  or  make 
other  improvements,  it  shall  be  deemed  to  apply  only  to  such  wharfs,  docks,  or  other  improve- 
ments as  are  not  leased,  as  provided  in  section  five  of  this  Act."'*' 


*  In  addition  to  the  Acts  herein  set  forth,  the  Legislature  of  the  State,  Session  of  1863,  passed  the  following, 
which  apply  specially  to  the  City  and  County  of  San  Francisco,  viz. : 

I.    Bridges.— Amendatory ;  plank  road  or  bridge  over  Mission  Bay.   (Act  CCCVII.    See  Statutes  1863, 
page  414.) 

II.    CoMMiBSiONER  OP  IMMIGRATION.— To  amend.    (Act  CXXyill,  page  151.) 

III.  Ferries.- Authorizing  the  Oakland  and  San  Antonio  S.  K.  Co.  to  maintain  a  wharf  and  ferry.  (Act 

CCCCXXII.  page  695. 

IV.  Fund  Commissioners.— Amendatory ;  to  settle  certain  claims.    (Act  LXXI,  page  69.) 

V.    Gas  Companiks.— Amendatory;   E.   L    Sullivan  and   others.    (Act  CLXXXVIII,  page  247.)    To 
authorize  A.  W.  Von  Schmidt  and  others  to  lay  down  gas  pipes,  etc.    (Act  CCXCIV,  page  395.) 

VI.  Gas  Pipes.- To  authorize  the  laying  down  of.    (Act  CCCCLII,  page  730.) 

VII.  Industrial  School.— Amendatory.    (Act  CLVI,  page  187.) 

VIII.  Jurors.— Amendatory.    (Act  CCCCI,  page  614.)

SAN    FRANCISCO     DIRECTORY 


ELECTION  DISTRICTS— as  established  by  the 
Coiniuiasioners  appointed  by  the  State  Legielatiire 
of  1856 : 

First  Dhtrict — Is  bounded  by  Kearny  Street  on 
the  west,  Pacilic  Street  on  the  south  and  the  Bay. 

Second  District — Is  bounded  by  Paciiic  Street  on 
the  south,  by  the  Bay  on  the  north,  Leavenworth 
Street  on  the  west,  and  Kearny  Street  on  tlie  east. 

Third  District — Is  bounded  by  Clay  Street  on 
the  south,  Paeific  Street  on  the  north,  Kearny  Street 
on  the  west,  and  the  Bay  on  the  east. 

Fourth  District — Is  bounded  by  Clay  Street  on 
the  south,  Pacitic  Street  on  the  north,  Larkiu  Street 
on  the  west,  and  Kearny  Street  on  the  east. 

Fifth  District — Is  bounded  by  Pine  Street  on  the 
south.  Clay  Street  on  the  north,  Kearny  Street  on 
the  west,  and  the  Bay  on  the  east. 

Sixth  District — Is  bounded  by  Pine  Street  on  the 
south,  by  Clay  Street  on  the  north.  l)y  Larkin  Street 
on  the  west,  and  by  Kearnv  Street  on  the  east. 

Seventh  District  — Is  tue  triangle  bounded  by 
Market,  Dupont,  and  Pine  streets. 

Eighth  District — Is  bounded  by  Market  Street  on 
the  south,  Piiie  Street  on  the  north,  Larkin  Street  on 
the  west,  and  Dupont  Street  on  the  east. 

Ninth  District — Is  the  trianjrle  bounded  by  Sec- 
ond Street,  Market  Street,  and  tlie  Bay. 

Tenth  District — Is  bounded  by  the  Bay,  Harris 
(now  Seventh) ,  Market,  and  Second  streets. 

Eleventh  District  —  Is  an  irregular  space  com- 
mencing at  tlie  foot  of  Seventh  Street,  running 
along  Seventh  to  Market,  aloug  Market  to  Larkin, 
along  Larkin  to  Bush,  along  Bush  to  the  boundary 
of  San  Mateo  County,  and  along  i  his  boundary  to  the 
place  of  beginning. 

Twelfth  District — Is  bounded  by  Bush  Street  on 
the  south,  the  Baj'  on  the  north,  the  boundary  of 
San  Jlateo  County  on  the  west,  and  Leavenworth 
and  Larkin  streets  on  the  east.

Fire  Department. 

The  Fire  Department  of  the  City  and  County  of 
San  Francisco  is  comj)osed  of  fourteen  Engine,  two 
Hook  and  Ladder,  aud  two  Hose  Companies,  num- 
bering 1,023  menibers.  Number  of  feet  of  hose, 
12,5t)0 — of  which  4,000  feet  is  of  an  ordinary  qual- 
ity. Number  of  hydrants  —  Bensley  W.  W.  Co., 
215;  Spring  Valley,  90;  total,  305.  Expenditures  of 
the  Department  per  annum,  including  the  salaries  of 
the  officers  and  beU-ringers  of  the  department,  re- 
pairs, etc.,  $48,000.

No.  1,  Broderick  Engine  Company. — House  sit- 
uated on  southerly  side  of  Sacramento  Street,  near 
Kearny.  Company  organized  April  14th,  1850  ;  ad- 
mitted into  the  Department  June  4th,  1850.  The 
house  is  two  stories  ni  bight ;  the  first  story  of  gran- 
ite and  the  second  of  brick  ;  constructed  in  the  Tudor 
style  of  architecture.  The  lot  is  18  feet  9  inches  by 
6^  feet  6  inches,  purchased  by  the  city  for  $6,656. 
The  house  was  built  by  the  city  at  a  cost  of  ^6,.500, 
of  which  amount  the  company  expended  $1,300. 
This  conipan)'  has  two  engines,  one  a  new  second 
class,  built  by  James  Smith  of  New  York,  size  of 
cylinders  85  inches,  stroke  9  inches ;  juirchased  by 
the  company  at  an  expense  of  $2,.')00.  The  other 
engine  is  of  the  Worth  style  and  cost  the  city  $5,000. 
The  company  has  sixty-five  active  members  on  the 
roll.  Stated  meetings  first  Friday  in  each  month. 
The  first  foreman  of  No.  1  was  David  C.  Broderick, 
who  was  succeeded  by  John  A.  McGlynn,  Geo.  W. 
Green,  David  Scannell,  and  John  Martin.  Officers 
— Foreman,  Edward  B.  Cotter;  Assistant,  Bernard 
Hagan ;  Secretary,  John  Brash;  Financial  Secre- 
tary, T.  B.  Tompkins ;  Treasurer,  John  Stratman. 

No.  2,  Alanhattan  Engine  Company. — House  sit- 
uated on  south  side  of  .Jackson  Street,  between 
Montgomery  and  Kearny.  Comjiany  organized 
January  31st,  1854;  admitted  into  the  Department 
February  4th,  1854.  The  house  now  occupied  by 
the  company  is  two  stories  in  bight,  the  first' is  of 
granite  and"  the  second  of  brick.  The  lot  is  22  feet 
6  inches  by  68  feet,  and  was  purchased  by  the  city 
and  cost  $7,200,  of  which  amount  the  companj'  ex- 
pended $700.  A  new  building  for  the  use  of  the 
company  is  being  completed  on  the  north  side  of 
O'Farrell  Street,  between  Dupont  and  Stockton.  It 
is  of  the  Italian  style  of  architecture,  22|  feet  wide 
by  63  feet  deep,  three  stories  in  bight  exclusive  of 
the  basement,  built  of  brown  stone  and  pressed 
brick,  and  will  cost,  including  the  price  paid  for  the 
lot,  $12,000,  the  entire  amount  paid  by  the  city. 
The  company  have  now  in  service  a  new  second 
class  engine,  built  by  Cowing  &  Co.,  Seneca  Falls, 
N.  Y.  Size  of  cylinders  85  inches ;  stroke  7^  inches. 
Cost  $2,000.  Is  the  property  of  the  city.  Stated 
meetings  first  Monday  of  each  month.  The  com- 
pany has  sixty-five  active  members  on  the  roll.  The 
first  foreman  was  David  L.  Beck,  succeeded  by 
Mathew  Mclntire,  as  acting  foreman,  and  Ira  Cole, 
D.  L.  Beck,  Thomas  J.  Smith,  John  D.  Swift,  L. 
Stivers,  and  the  present  foreman.  Officers — Fore-

Chas.  H.  Boel ;  Treasurer,  W.  A.  Field.

No.  6,  Monumental  Engine  Company. — House 
situated  on  Brenham  Place,  between  W  ashington 
and  Clav  streets.  Company  organized  September 
lOtli,  1850 ;  admitted  into  the  Department  Septem- 
ber 12th,  1850.  The  house  is  two  stories  in  hight, 
the  first  of  granite,  the  second  of  free-stone,  and  is 
of  the  Corinthian  style  of  architecture.  The  lot  is 
25  by  65  feet,  purchased  by  the  city  for  $16,000 ;  the 
house,  which  contains  a  fine  library  of  over  one 
thousand  volumes,  was  built  by  the  city  and  cost 
$10,500,  of  which  amount  the  company"  expended 
$4,(j00.  This  company  has  a  steam  engine,  built  by 
Lee  &  Lamed,  Novelty  Works,  New  York  city. 
Annular  boiler,  rotary  pumps ;  weight,  6,300  pounds. 
Cost  $5,.500.  This  is  the  pioneer  steam  engine  of 
the  State,  it  having  been  received  by  way  of  Pan- 
ama, per  "John  L.  Stephens,"  September  2d,  1860, 
and  placed  in  active  service  February  2d,  1861.  The 
company  has  sixty-five  active  members  on  the  roll. 
Stated  meetings  first  Tuesday  of  each  month.  The 
first  foreman  of  No.  6  was  George  H.  Hossefross,

Exempt  Fire_  Company. — Organized  in  accord- 
ance with  Section  1.5  of  an  Act  of  the  Legislature 
"  To  regulate  the  Fire  Department  of  the  city  of  San 
Francisco,"  approved  March  25th,  1857,  which  read 
as  follows  :  "Exempt  members  of  the  Department 
may  organize  themselves  to  be  known  and  desig- 
nated as  the  Exempt  Fire  Company,  etc.,  and  shall 
be  entitled  to  equal  relief  from  the  Fire  Department 
Charitable  Fund  ;  but  they  shall  have  no  vote,  or 
other  representation  in  the  Depaiiment.' '  The  Legis- 
lature of  the  State,  March  16,  1863,  passed  an  Act 
appropriating  $8,000  to  be  expended  in  repairing  the 
building  now  occupied  by  Manhattan  Engiue  Com- 
pany, No.  2,  which  is  set  apart  for  the  use  of  the 
company,  and  for  the  purchase  of  a  suitable  apparatus. 
Oplccrs — Presicient,  G.  H.  Hoseefross  ;  Vice  Presi- 
dent, William  W.  Haney ;  Treasurer,  Ch.irlcs  R. 
Bond;  Secretary,  G.  J.  ilobe.  Annual  election  of 
officers,  second  Monday  in  October.  Stated  meet- 
ings, second  Monday  of  every  month.    Admission 


fre,  $5;  quarterlj'  dues,  ,$1.  Meetinm,  for  the  pre 
sent,  heW  at  the  rooms  of  the  Boarci  of  Delegates. 
Uuraber  of  members,  105.

MARINE    HOSPITAL. 

J.  HASTINGS,  Surgeon  and  Physician. 


U.  S.   Brancli  Mint, 

North    Side   of    Commercial,    near    Montgomery/. 

The  law  for  the  establishment  and  regulation  of 
the  United  States  Jlint,  and  the  branches  thereof, 
provides  that  any  person  may  deposit  with  the  offi- 
cers in  charge  of  the  same,  gold  and  silver  in  bullion, 
grain,  or  lumps,  which,  if  requested,  shall  be  refined, 
assayed,  and  cast  into  bars  or  coined,  as  speedily  as 
possible  after  the  receipt  thereof,  the  bars  to  be 
stamped  in  said  mint  or  branches,  in  such  manuer  as 
shall  indicate  the  weight,  fineness,  and  value  of  the 
same ;  the  expense  incurred  to  be  retained  from 
each  deposit  so  made,  at  such  rates  and  charges,  and 
under  such  regulations,  as  may  from  time  to  time  be 
established.  The  said  charges  not  to  exceed  the 
actual  cost  of  refining,  casting,  and  forming  said 
bars,  including  labor,  wastage,  use  of  machinery, 
material,  etc.,  or  i  per  cent,  for  coinage,  to  be 
received  by  the  Treasurer  of  the  Mint  at  which  the 
deposit  was  made,  and  by  him  accounted  for  to  the 
Treasurer  of  the  United  States. 

Office  hours  from  !)  o'clock  A.  m.  to  2  p.  M.  Gold 
Bullion  received  daily  from  9  o'clock  a.  m.  to  12  m.  ; 
Silver  Bullion  from  12  m.  to  1  P.  M.  Visitors  ad- 
mitted daily  from  9  o'clock  a.  m.  to  12  o'clock  M. 

ROBERT  B.  SWAIN,  Superintendent. 

D.  W.  Cheesman,  Treasm-er. 

Benjamin  T.  Martin,  Assayer;  H.  H.  Lawrence, 
Assistant  Assayer;  Walter  S.  Denio,  Melter  and 
Refiner;  JohnM.  Eckfeldt,  Assistant  do. ;  William 
Schmolz,  Coiner;  Adolphus  Schmolz,  Assistant  do. ;

Post  Office. 

North-west  corner  Washington  and  Battery.  Of- 
fice hoiu's  from  8  o'clock  a.  m.  to  5  p.  m.

son, Registry  Clerk  ;  Robert  L.  Taylor,  Box  Clerk  ; 
Augustus  C.  Stevens,  Stamp  Clerk ;  Cliristian  A. 
Uhrig,  Samuel  J.  Hegeman,  and  Isaac  Naylor, 
Transcript  Clerks ;  Gustavus  W.  Clapp,  John  W. 
Jessup,  Chester  S.  Kasson,  and  Frank  E.  Dyer, 
Assistant  Mailing  Clerks;  ChiU-les  Carl,  George"  A. 
CaiiRS,  WariiMi  P.  Adams,  Henry  C.  Squire,  Ed- 
ward li.  Jerome,  and  Albert  R.  Gunnison,  Delivery 
Clerks ;  George  A.  Tilden,  Newspaper  Clerk  ;  John 
E.  Magarry,  Assistant  Newspaper  ClerK;  Edward 
T.  Dudley,"  Clerk  :  George  C.  Harriman,  Secretary ; 
John  Dempsey  (colored).  Porter. 

Great  Overland  Mail  from  San  Francisco  to  St. 
Joseph,  Mo.,  via  Salt  Lake,  leaves  daily  (except 
Sundays)  at  4  o'clock  P.  M.  Mail  closes  at  Jj 
o'clock  p.  M. 

English  closed  mail,  closes  Wednesdays  and  Sat- 
urdays, at  3  o'clock  p.  M. 

Mails  for  Sacramento  and  the  Northern  Mines 
closes  daily  at  3:45  v.  u. ;  for  Benicia,  Vallejo,  etc., 
at  the  same  hour. 

Mails  for  Stockton  and  the  Southern  Mines  close 
daily  at  3: 1;»  p.  m. 

Mails  for  San  Jos6,  etc.,  closed  daily  at  7:45  a.  m. 

Mails  for  Santa  Barbara,  Los  Angeles,  and  San 
Diego,  are  dispatched  7^  o'clock,  daily. 

Mails  for  Acapulco,  Panama,  and  South  America, 
are  forwarded  on  the  3d,  13th,  and  23d,  of  each 
month,  and  close  at  fifteen  minutes  past  eight  a.  m., 
on  the  morning  of  the  sailing  of  the  steamer. 

Mails  for  China,  the  Sandwich  Islands,  and  Aus- 
tralia, are  forwarded  from  the  Post  Office  by  every 
suitable  opportunity,  containing  all  letters  and  papers, 
the  inland  postage  of  which  is  prepaid  to  San  Fran- 
cisco, leaving  the  sea  postage  to  be  collected  in  the 
ports  where  the  mails  are  delivered. 

Letters  should  be  fully  prepaid  by  stamps.  Drop 
Letters  must  be  prepaid  by  postage  stamps.  Letters 
will  not  be  sent  with  stamps  cut  from  stamped  en- 
velops. 

All  printed  matter  is  now  forwarded  to  the  East 
by  steamer,  on  the  3d,  13th,  and  23d,  of  each 
month.

Justice,  C.  Cornell ;  Constable,  Mighill  Smith  ;  office, 
528  Montgomery. 

Fourth  Toivnship — Seventh  and  Eiifhth  Dis- 
tricts.—Justice,  George  Robins ;  Constable,  Joshua 
Hilton  ;  office,  230  Bush  near  Montgomery. 

Fifth  Township — Ni7ith  and  Tenth  Districts. — 
Justice,  Geo.  Fisher ;  Constable,  Philip  H.  Blake  ; 
office,  613  Market  near  Second. 

Si.xth  Township— Eleventh  and  Twelfth  Dis- 
tricts.—J  uetice,  Martin  W.  Lamb  ;  Constable,  Irwin 
S.  Lamb;  office,  Valencia  near  Fifteenth.

SAN  FRANCISCO  DIRECTORY. 


CHURCHES. 


BAPTIST. 

First  Baptist  Church. 
Eev.  D.  B.  Chkney,  Pastor;  location,  north  side 
Washington  near  Stockton.    Pastor's  residence  and 
study,  1417  Taylor  Street,  near  Jackson. 

This  church  was  organized  in  June,  1849,  under 
the  labors  of  its  first  Pastor,  Rev.  0.  C.  Wheeler. 
The  clmrcb  lot  was  purchased  in  the  spring  of  the 
year,  for  the  sum  of  $10,000.  The  first  house  of 
worship  was  dedicated  in  August,  1849,  and  was  the 
first  Protestant  house  of  worship  erected  in  Califor- 
nia. Mr.  Wheeler's  pastorate  ended  in  November, 
1851,  who  was  succeeded  by  Rev.  B.  Brierly  in 
May,  1852.  In  the  summer  "and  fall  of  1853,  the 
wooden  building  was  removed,  and  the  basement  of 
the  present  edifice  was  erected  at  a  cost  of  $13,000. 
In  this,  the  chinch  wiirshipped  until  September, 
1857,  when  it  dedicated  its  newly-tinisbed  building 
which  it  had  completed  for  the  sum  of  $1(),()00,  in- 
cluding upholstery.  The  church  edifice  has  been 
recently  placed  in  complete  repair,  and  newly  fur- 
nished throughout ;  and  during  the  administration  of 
the  present  pastor,  who  commenced  his  labors  in 
July,  1859,  large  accessions,  both  to  the  church  and 
congregation,  have  been  made. 

Number  of  communicants,  305.  The  Sunday  School 
has  an  average  attendance  of  about  350.  ^Number 
of  enrolled,  450.  The  library  contains  over  3,700 
volumes. 

Sabbath  services  morning  and  evening;  S;ibbath 
School  at  1  P.  M.  Prayer  Meeting  every  Wednes- 
day evening;  Sabbath  School  Teachers'  Meeting 
held  on  three  Friday  evenings  of  each  month,  con- 
]  ducted  by  the  Pastor;  Church  Covenant  Meeting 
the  Friday  evening  preceding  the  first  Sabbath  in 
each  month.  Sunday  School  Concert,  second  Sab- 
bath evenhig,  each  month. 

Officei-H — Deacons:  Abraham  Hobson,  A.  B.  For- 
bes, D.  N.  Breed,  and  J.  F.  Pope  ;  Trustees:  John 
F.  Pope,  A.  B.  Forbes,  P.  Sather,  Isaac  Lanker- 
shim,  and  Harry  Garthwaite  ;  Clerk :  Leonard  S. 
Clark;  Treasurer:  I).  C.  Breed;  Superintendent  of 
Sabbath  Scliool :  B.  T.  Martin ;  Assistant  Superin- 
tendent :  A.  B.  Forbes ;  Se(-retary  and  Treasurer : 
Cassias  Conro;  Librarian:  Henry  Tibbey. 

This  church  hiis  ilit^missed  51  of  its  members  to 
form  the  Secmid  r>;iptist  Cliurch,  and  transferred  to 
said  church  its  MitJsion  Sunday  School  and  pro[)erty 
on  Fifth  Street.  But  for  this,  it  would  have  shown 
a  large  increase  of  members  during  the  past  year. 

Second  Baptist  Church. 

Eev.  IIjenuy  A.  SAWTEr.i.K,  Pastor;  residence  on 
Turk  street,  north  side,  between  Taylor  and  Jones. 
The  house  of  worship  is  located  on  i'ifth  Street,  near 
Market. 

This  church  was  organized  the  22d  day  of  De- 
cember, 1862,  with  41  constituent  mernbers,  to 
whom  nearly  as  many  more  niembers  have  been 
since  added.  The  membersbiii  has  been  supplied 
very  largely  from  the  First  Baptist  Churcli,  by 
which  the  new  interest  was  sustained  until  it  ma- 
tured into  an  independent  organization.  At  the  time 
of  the  formation  of  the  new  church,  the  First 
Churcli  had  sustained  iu  the  same  location  a  Sunday 
School  two  years,  and  an  evangelist  one  year,  be- 
sides building  the  *hapel  now  occupied  by  the  Sec- 
ond Chuveli.  The  present  officers  of  the  churchj 
aside  fiom  pastor,  are  as  follows :

Third  Baptist  Church  (Colored). 

Rev.  Thoma.s  Howell,  Pastor;  location,  east 
side  of  Dupoiit  Street,  between  Filbert  and  Green- 
wich ;  residence  of  the  Pastor,  north  side  of  Oak 
Street,  near  Taylor. 

This  church  was  organized  in  1854.  It  owns  its 
church  property  free  of  debt.  The  present  pastor 
began  to  supply  the  church  some  four  years  ago, 
and  was  ordained  about  two  years  ago.  Under  his 
ministry  the  church  has  been  much  prospered  and 
increased  in  numbers  and  efliciency.  It  has  about 
80  members.  E.  W.  Parker  is  Church  Clerk.  Serv- 
ices every  Sabbath  at  3  and  7|  o'clock,  p.  m.  Sab- 
bath school,  8  teachers,  44  scholars. 


CON  GREGATION  AL. 

First  Congregational  Church. 

Rev.  Edward  S.  Lacy,  Pastor;  location,  south- 
west corner  of  California  and  Dupont.  Pastor's 
residence,  1001  Powell  corner  Clay. 

Preaching  every  Sabbath  at  11  o'clock,  a.  m.,  and 
7|  p.  M. ;  Lecture  every  Wednesday  evening  at  7^ 
o'clock;  Sabbath  School  immediately  after  morning 
service. 

Officers  of  Church — Deacons:  L.  B.  Benchley, 
W.  O.  Ayres,  M.D.,  Lyman  Dickerman,  J.  W. 
Clark,  M.'D.,  J.  T.  Boyd.  Stauding  Committee  :  A. 
C.  Nichols,  E.  D.  SaAvyer,  and  A.  G.  Stiles. 

Officers  of  the  Society — Ira  P.  Rankin,  Modera- 
tor;  J.  W.  Clark,  Clerk  and  Treasurer;  Trustees: 
J.  W.  Clark,  H.  L.  Dodge,  Wm.  A.  Dana,  A.  C. 
Nichols,  Iru  P.  Rankin,  and  A.  G.  Stiles. 

This  cliurch,  or  congregation,  was  organized  July 
29,  1849,  when  Thomas  Douglas  and  Frederick  S. 
Ilawley  were  chosen  Deacons,  and  inducted  into 
ofiice  on  the  following  Sunday,  by  Rev.  T.  D.  Hunt, 
assisted  by  Rev.  A .  Williams.  The  society  met  in 
the  school  house,  on  the  Plaza,  until  it  was  required 
for  other  purposes,  when  the  members  were  de- 
prived of  a  regular  place  of  meeting  for  several 
months.  As  early  as  practicable,  however,  elfoits 
were  made  for  the  erection  of  a  suitable  house  of 
worship,  which  resulted  in  the  building  of  a  commo- 
dious frame  structure,  25  by  50  feet,  on  the  corner 
of  Jackson  and  Virginia  streets,  which  was  dedi- 
cated to  the  worship  of  God,  February  10,  1850. 
Rev.  T.  D.  Hunt  was  chosen  Pastor,  and  installed 
June  26,  1850,  who,  in  this  connection,  it  is  proper 
to  state,  was  the  first  Protestant  clergyman,  located 
as  such,  in  the  State,  having  arrived  at  San  Fran- 
cisco as  early  as  October  29,  1848,  and  was  immed- 
iately invited  by  the  citizens,  in  a  meeting  called  for 
the  pur]i(ise,  to  act  as  their  chaplain  for  one  year, 
coiiiineiieing  November  1,  1848,  in  which  capacity 
he  was  laboring  at  the  time  of  the  organization  of 
this  church.  The  congregation  increased  so  greatly 
as  to  require  a  larger  house;  accordingly  measures 
were  adopted  in  the  summer  of  1852,  for  the  erec- 
tion of  the  present  substantial  brick  edifice,  which 
was  dedicated  on  the  10th  of  Julj,  1853.  Rev.  E. 
S.  Lacy,  the  present  Pastor,  was  installed  July  6th, 
1856. 

The  whole  number  of  members  admitted  to  the 
church  since  its  organization  is  524.  The  piesent 
membership  is  375.    The  cost  of  the  present  church

EPISCOPAL. 

Grace  Cathedral. 

Right  Rev.  Bishop  Kip  and  Rev.  G.  A.  Ea.stos 
officiating.  Location,  corner  California  and  Stockton 
streets. 

Public  services  every  Sunday  at  11a.  m.  and  7\?. 
M. ;  Sunday  School  at  naif  past  nine  in  the  morning. 
The  congregation  was  organized  in  1849,  the  statis- 
tics of  wliich  may  be  summed  up  as  follows  :  Com- 
municants, 300  ;  the  Sunday  School  numbers  about 
200  scholars,  and  has  a  library  of  over  300  volumes. 
The  first  Rector  of  the  church  was  Dr.  J.  L.  Ver 
Mehr,  who  preached  his  first  sermon  in  California  at 
the  house  of  Mr.  Merrill,  in  this  city,  September  10th, 
1849.  The  church  was  then  in  embryo,  not  yet 
having  been  duly  organized.  A  party  of  gentlemen 
soon  after  invited  Dr.  Ver  Mehr  to  jH'each  at  Frank 
Ward's  house,  situated  on  the  corner  of  Stockton 
and  Green  streets.  A  chapel  was  next  built  toward 
the  close  of  1849,  at  the  coiner  of  John  and  Powell 
streets,  which  was  first  opened  for  divine  services, 
December  30th,  1849.  This  was  the  first  Grace 
Church.  It  was  60  feet  long  by  20  feet  wide,  and 
cost  §8,000.  The  liell  is  that 'used  in  the  former 
church,  on  Powell  Street.  It  weighs  800  pounds, 
cost  $350,  and  has  called  the  faithful  to  prayers  from 
the  first.  It  was  presented  by  Mr.  Frank  Ward. 
On  the  28th  of  April,  18.50,  Grace  Church  was  for- 
mally organized,  and  came  into  being.  E.  Bryant 
and  D.  S.  Turner  were  elected  Wardens,  and  Dr. 
Ver  Mehr  chosen  Rector.  The  first  vestry  meeting 
was  held  on  May  20th,  1850— thirteen  years  ago.  In 
February,  1851,  the  contract  was  made  to  build  the 
former  Grace  Church  on  Powell  Street,  which  was 
finished  that  summer.  Dr.  Ver  Mehr  preached  the 
first  sermon  in  this  edifice.  Bishop  Kip  arrived  in 
San  Francisco  January  29th,  1854,  and  on  the  25th 


of  February  following,  assumed  the  Rectorship,  at 
which  time  Dr.  Ver  Mehr  resigned.  The  Bishop 
continued  to  officiate  until  Palm  Sunday,  April  5th, 
1857,  when  F.  C.  Ewer  was  ordained,  ano  on  the 
next  Sunday  he  pre;;ched  his  first  sermon.  On  the 
14th  of  April  Mr.  Ewer  was  elected  to  be  Assistant 
j\Iinieter,  and  on  the  ;.!Oth  of  the  same  month  he  took 
charge  of  the  parish,  the  Bisliop  having  departed  for 
the  Atlantic  States.  The  Bishop  having  returned 
and  resigned  the  Rectorship,  Mr.  Ewer  was  elected 
Rector  of  the  Church  on  the  1.5th  of  December,  1857, 
and  retained  tluit  position  until  April,  1861,  when  he 
resigned. 

The  congregation  have  erected  at  the  south-east 
corner  Stockton  and  California  streets,  a  commodi- 
ous and  substantial  church  edifice,  as  the  Cathedral 
Church  of  the  Diocese,  which  will  be,  when  fully 
completed,  one  of  the  finest  church  buildings  on  the 
coast.  The  church  will  cover  an  area  of  137 1  feet 
by  68  feet,  and  will  contain  within  its  walls  every 
convenience  necessary  to  carry  out  the  holy  objects 
for  which  it  was  erected. 

Officers — Senior  "\\'arden  :  Win.  Blanding.  Junior 
Warden  :  Geo.  W.  Gibhs.  Vestrymen  :  Edw.  Prin- 
gle,  Stephen  Smith,  Alex.  Ely,  l\.  F.  Williams,  H. 
C.  Parker,  Jos.  S.  Winans,  Nat.  Holland,  and  C.  0. 
Gerberding. 

Trinity  Church. 

The  Rev.  Christopher  B.  Wyatt,  Rector. 

Pastor's  residence,  No.  812  Bush  Street. 

(;hurch  located  north  side  I'ine  between  Mont- 
gomery and  Kearny.     Organized,  18:19. 

Public  worship  every  Sunday  11  a.  M.and?!  P.M.; 
Wednesday  11  a.  m.,"  and  Friday  4  p.  m.;  Sunday 
School  9  a!  M. 

Officers — Senior  Warden:  J.  D.  Hawks;  Junior 
Warden :  B.  II.  Randolph ;  Vestrymen :  S.  R. 
Throckmorton,  W.  F.  Babcock,  Louis  McLane,  Jas. 
Bell,  J.  C.  McCeney,  W.  L.  Booker,  Jacob  Under- 
bill, J.  W.  Dwiiielle,  J.  T.  Dean,  Geo.  H.  Howard, 
H.  S.  Dexter;  Jos.  G.  Eastland,  Clerk  of  Vestry. 

St.  John's  Church,  Mission  Dolores. 

Rev.  T.  W.  Brotherton,  Rector. 

This  church  was  established  in  November,  1857 — 
the  Rev.  Jolm  Chittenden,  President  of  the  San 
Francisco  College,  then  a  lay  reader,  licensed  by  the 
Bishop  of  the  Diocese,  officiating  as  its  Minister. 
The  parish,  of  which  this  is  the  church,  was  insti- 
tuted in  February,  1S58,  and  it  is  now  in  a  state  of 
forwardness,  to  be  permanently  received  as  such  into 
the  Diocese  of  California.  It  is  the  Protestant  Epis- 
copal Church,  and  has  all  the  privileges  of  other 
churches  in  the  Episcopate.  It  is  a  neat  edifice,  and 
is  thoroughly  fiirnislied  with  organ,  robing-room, 
altar,  pulpit,  aud  vestment.  The  inhabitants  are  in- 
debted mainly  to  the  liberality  of  a  few  individuals 
and  to  the  Rev.  John  Chittenden  for  the  first  intro- 
duction of  this  church  service  into  the  neighborhood. 
The  Rev.  J.  Cameron,  ordained  in  April,  1860,  offi- 
ciated as  Curate — the  Rev.  J.  Chittenden  being  hie 
Rector.  By  the  energy  of  the  Curate,  assisted  by 
his  brother  clergymen,  lie  has  established  the  Episco- 
pal Church  permanently  in  this  vicinity.  Services 
are  held  at  11  a.  m.  aiid  7^  p.  m.  Sundays.  It  is 
worthy  of  being  noted  that  the  Jliiiisters,  Organist, 
Choir,"  and  other  assistants,  give  their  services  gra- 
tuitously. The  present  Rector  took  charge  the  1st  day- 
August,  A.  D.  1861.  The  1st  of  August,  '62,  a  church 
edifice  was  commenced,  on  a  lot  presented  by  the 
ladies  of  the  congregation  to  the  Vestry,  which  was 
finished  in  November  of  the  same  year.  The  new 
church  is  built  in  the  early  English  First  pointed 
style,  at  a  cost  of  $S,.500,  with  furniture,  etc.,  and  is 
capable  of  accommodating  250  i)crsons.  The  Sunday 
School  numbers  about  150  scholars  and  ten  teachers. 
W.  0.  Andrews,  Superintendent.

SAN  FRANCISCO  DIRECTORY, 


Church  of  the  Advent. 

Kev.  F.  Mauio.v  McAllister,  Rector. 

The  Piirisli  wiis  estiiblished,  with  its  first  and  pres- 
ent Rector,  June,  IS.'jH. 

Tills  clmrcli  is  located  on  Howard  Street  between 
Second  and  Third  street.*.  It  was  completed  and 
consecnited  February  "J  1th,  I8G]. 

Services  every  Sunday  at  11  a.  m.  and  "i  p.  m.  ; 
Sunday  School  at  9  a.  m. 

Offit.er.t — Wardens:  H.  S.  Austin,  sen.,  and  Cut- 
ler McAllister,  jr. :  \'e.stryuicn  :  L.  A.  Garnett,  C.  A. 
Eastman,  E.  B.  Hpnj.uuin,  J.  Van  Dyke,  T.  R.  .lolm- 
8on,  Hall. McAllister,  and  C.  Langley. 

The  new  church,  with  its  lofty  steeple,  forms  a 
conspicuous  object  in  the  sonthcm  part  of  the  city. 
The  architecture  is  nearly  pure  Gothic.  Some  modi- 
fications in  the  Romanesque  style  have  been  intro- 
duced, adding  materially  to  the  light  and  graceful 
effect.  The  exterior  is  of  a  rich  dark  brown,  and, 
with  its  lofty  lantern,  reminds  one  of  "  St.  Dunstan's 
in  the  Ea.st,"  London,  built  by  Sir  Christopher 
Wren,  and  copied  by  him  from  the  fine  old  cliurch  of 
St.  Nicholas,  New  Castle,  England. 

The  interior  is  plain  and  elegant,  and  offering  an 
auditorium  in  the  clear  of  fifty  feet  by  eighty,  or  one 
hundred  and  twenty  feet  in  depth  with  tlie  chancel. 
The  walls  are  painted  in  imitation  of  stone,  the  ceil- 
ing, wliich  is  divided  with  delicate  tracery,  springs 
gi-adually  to  the  apex  of  the  roof,  and  is  painted  light 
blue.  The  chancel  is  a  model  of  neat,  nnpretending 
architecture,  and  with  the  pnlpit,  whicli  is  very 
high,  is  much  in  the  old  English  style.  A  very 
attractive  feature  is  the  Ten  Couimandmeuts,  which 
fill  up  the  niches  at  the  rear  of  the  chancel.  The 
windows  are  lofty  and  divided  into  diamond-shaped 
sections  by  a  lattice  work  of  wood  on  the  inside. 

The  lot,  with  the  edifice  and  furuiiure,  cost  the 
society  $27,000. 


METHODIST    EPISCOPAL.

o'clock  on  Sal)bath. 

Officers — Class  Leader:  C.L.Newmans;  Stew- 
ards: John  C.  Ayers,  John  Stevens,  Richard  W.

Howard  Street  Methodist  Episcopal  Church. 
Kev.  J.  1).  IJi.Ai.N,  Pastor;  residence,  rear  of 
church.  Location,  Howard  Street,  between  Second 
and  Third.  Sunday  morning  and  evening  service 
at  the  usual  hours  ;  seats  free.    Sunday  School  at  2 


p.  M.  Prayer  Meeting,  etc.,  on  Wednesday  eve- 
ning. 

This  Society,  organized  in  1852,  under  the  super- 
intendence of  Rev.  Isaac  Owen,  erected,  and  dedi- 
cated Deceudier  5th,  18.53,  a  plain,  but  substantial, 
neatly  furnished  house  of  worship.  The  Society  has 
a  valuable  property,  and  is  out  of  debt.  The  num- 
ber of  connnunicants  was,  in  September,  1858,  70 ; 
since  which  280  have  been  added ;  making  in  all 
3.50,  up  to  August,  1863.  A  good  religious  interest 
pervades  the  Society.  Sabbath  School  Superintend- 
ent, William  H.  Codington;  number  of  teachers, 
34  ;  scholars,  408;  volumes  in  the  library,  1.200. 

Tlie  lot  formerly  occupied  by  tliis  Society  on  Fol- 
som  Street,  was  sold  in  September,  1S(')2,  to  W.  F. 
Babcock,  for  $7,750.  About  the  same  time,  a  lot 
was  bought  on  the  corner  of  Howard  and  Hubbard 
streets,  112^  feet  on  Howard  by  137^  feet  on  Hub- 
bard, at  a  cost  of  $14,750. 

The  church  now  being  erected  is  Gothic  of  the 
fourteenth  century,  ninety-six  feet  loni;  by  fifty- 
eight  feet  wide,  it  will  seat,  when  finished,  1,000 
persons.  It  will  cost,  exclusive  of  the  lot,  about 
$^0,000.  The  whole  indebtedness  of  the  property, 
will  be  about  $15,000. 

The  membei  ship  is  now  about  350.  The  average 
number  in  attendance  at  the  Sabbath  School  for  July, 
1863,  was  405.

J.  W.  Wliiting,  S.  H.  Hancock,  Daniel  S.  Howard. 

Bethel  Methodist  Episcopal  Chtirch. 

Rev.  A.  Bland,  Pastor;  residence,  rear  of  the 
church  ;  location.  Mission  between  First  and  Second 
streets. 

This  church  was  organized  early  in  1851,  under 
the  pastoral  charge  of  Rev.  W.  Taylor.  Service 
was  then  held  in  the  ship  Panama,  on  Davis  Street. 
Subsequently  the  ship  was  moved  to  the  foot  of  Mis- 
sion Street,  and  a  church  built  on  deck.  Early  in 
1857,  the  church  was  taken  down  and  rebuilt  in  its 
present  eligible  situation. 

During  the  past  year  this  church  has  enjoj'ed  a 
constant  prosperity.     Its  membership  is  over  100.

and  evening.     Sabbath  School  at  9^  a.  m.

P  E  E  S  B  Y  T  E  R  I  A  N  . 

First  Presbyterian  Church. 

Rev.  W.  C.  Anderson,  D.I).,  I'astor.  Resi- 
dence 1008  Powell  between  Clay  and  Washington. 
Location,  Stockton  Street  near  Clay.  Services  on 
Sabbath  at  11  a.  m.  and  7^  p.  ,m.  Sabbath  School 
and  Bible  Class  at  1  o'clock,  p.  m.  Lecture  Wed- 
nesday evening  at  7|  o'clock. 

This  church  was  organized  May  20th,  1849,  under 
the  direction  of  Rev.  Albert  Williams,  and  was  the 
first  Protestant  Church  organized  in  San  Francisco. 
W.  W.  Caldwell,  Frederick  Billings,  Dr.  Creorge  F. 
Turner,  Mrs.  Sarah  B.  Gillesjiie,  Mrs.  Ann  Hodgson, 
and  Mrs.  Margaret  A.  Geary,  were  the  original 
memhers  ;  Capt.  B.  Simmons,  p].  Woodruff,  and  H. 
Giimes,  were  the  first  Trustees. 

During  the  summer  of  1819,  the  congregation  wor- 
shiped in  a  tent  on  Dupont  Street,  afterward  in  a 
store-room  of  the  Custom  House,  and  in  the  Supe- 
rior Court  Room,  City  Hall,  until  January  19th, 
1851,  when  a  ueat  Gotliic  edifice,  capable  of  hold- 
ing 700  persons,  was  dedicated.  This  house  was 
destroyed  by  the  great  fire  of  22d  June,  1851.  A 
plain  building  was  immediately  erected,  in  which 
the  congre<ration  worshiped  until  August,  1857  ;  and 
from  that  time  till  May,  1858,  their  meetings  were 
held  in  the  Chinese  Mission  Chapel.  Their  present 
fine  house  of  worship  was  built  in  the  stmnncr  iuid 
autumn  of  1857,  at  a  cost  of  about  $.50,0(10,  including 
the  lot,  fui'niture,  and  fixtures.  It  is  in  the  Gntliic 
style  of  architecture  throughout.  The  main  build- 
ing is  117  feet  long,  or  to  the  outside  of  the  tower 
123  feet ;  and  is  61  feet  wide.  Rooms  for  the  Pas- 
tor's stud}-  and  social  meetings  are  on  the  same  floor 
with  the  audience  room,  which  last  is  81  by  58  feet, 
with  a  ceiling  39  feet  high.  A  Sabbath  School  room, 
57  by  36,  is  over  the  front  apartments  ;  on  the  north- 
east corner  of  the  house  is  a  brick  tower,  96  feet  in 
hight.  There  is  an  organ  gallery  that  will  seat  a 
choir  of  40  persons.  In  all  its  arrangements  the 
edifice  is  admirable  adapted  to  its  purpose,  and  at 
the  same  time  is  in  accordance  with  true  architect- 
ural taste. 


Officers— Tlev.  W.  C.  Anderson,  D.D.,  Pastor; 
R.  H.  Waller,  N.  Gray,  S.  Hopkins,  and  .)o!in  Bev- 
ans.  Elders;  Trustees:  James  Bowman,  President, 
James  K.  S.  Latham,  Secretary,  Win.  N.  Arthur, 
R.  B.  Fordham,  E.  J.  Crane,  James  Folger,  Joseph 
Gordon . 

The  Church  is  in  a  very  prosperous  condition. 
Present  number  of  communicants,  250.  S.  B.  Stod- 
dard Superintendent  Sabbath  School.  No.  of  schol-

to  the  school. 

Calvary  Presbyterian  Church. 

Rev.  Charles  WAnwwouTH,  D.D.,  Paslor;  resi- 
dence, north  side  of  Pine  street  between  M.isou  and 
Taylor.  Location,  north  side  of  Bush  Street  between 
Montgomery  and  Sansora.  Services  every  Sabbath 
at  11  A.  M.  and  7  p.  m.,  hi  winter  months,  and  at 
7^  p.  M.  in  summer.  Public  Lecture  Wednesday 
evening ;  Prayer  Meeting  Sabbath  evening,  one 
hour  before  the  evening  service.  Young  JVIen's 
Prayer  jMeeting  on  Saturday  evening.  Sabbath 
School  every  Sabbath  at  9i  a.  m.,  James  B.  Rob- 
erts, Superintendent. 

Officers — Elders:  R.  I\IcKee,  Henry  P.  Coon, 
James  D.  Thornton,  James  B.  Roberts;  Deacon: 
Edward  Hagthrop;  Trustees:  F.  Henderson,  Alex- 
ander Campbell,  James  B.  Roberts,  H.  H.  Haight, 
Thomas  H.  Selby,  C.  Wittram,  Charles  H.  Rey- 
nolds, C.  Clayton,  and  H.  M.  Newhall. 

This  Church  was  erected  in  the  fall  of  1854,  at  a 
cost,  including  the  lot,  of  about  $70,000.  On  its 
completion,  the  property  was  largely  in  debt,  but 
the  debt  was  gradually  reduced,  and  finally  wholly 
extinguished.  The  whole  property  is  now  entirely 
free  from  debt,  and  the  income  of  the  church,  now 
some  ,$13,000,  from  pew  rents  and  Sabbath  collec- 
tions is  ample  to  meet  all  its  current  expenses.  The 
church  has  a  splendid  organ,  built  by  Henry  Erhen, 
of  New  York,  which  cost  over  $8,000.  This  is,  in 
all  respects,  the  largest  and  most  costly  organ  on  the 
Pacific  coast,  and  it  has  few  superiors  even  in  the 
Atlantic  States.  It  has  46  stops,  and  over  2,000 
pipes.  The  greatest  variety  of  combinations  can  be 
made  by  the  use  of  the  various  stops  and  c(ui])lings; 
and  for  e.vcellence  of  workmanship,  and  sweetness 
of  tone,  it  has  been  pronounced  by  judges  to  be  un- 
surpassed. Tlie  choir  is  under  the  etticieiit  manage- 
ment of  Mr.  Washington  Elliot,  Mr.  (Justave  A. 
Scott  being  the  oi'gaiiist. 

The  church  building  will  seat  comfortably  1,000 
persons.  The  number  of  comiiumicants  is  now 
about  425.  The  number  of  scholais  and  te.udiers  in 
the  Sabbath  School  is  about  300  ;  number  of  volumes 
in  the  library  1,000,  which  were  selected  with  great 
care,  and  form  a  very  complete  library.  Connected 
with  the  Church  is  a  depository  of  the  books  of  the 
Presbyterian  Board  of  Publication,  in  which  there 
is  kept  a  variety  of  the  standard  books  and  tracts 
published  by  that  Board. 

Howard  Street  (N.  S.)  Presbyterian  Church. 

Pastor — Vacant.  Location— Corner  Natoma  and 
Jane,  near  Howard  Street. 

Organized  September,  1850,  to  supply  a  portion  of 
the  city  (Happy  Valley)  then  destitute  of  religious 
privileges.  Uiider  the  auspices  of  the  late  pastor, 
Rev.  S.  H.  Willey,  the  building  at  present  occupied 
by  the  congregation  was  dedicated  June  17,  1851. 
It  was  enlarged  and  thorougly  repaired  in  1861,  and 
now  contains  a  neat  and  coimucKiious  Audience 
Room,  besides  Lecture  Room,  S;ibbath  School  Room, 
etc.,  in  the  basement. 

Rev.  Abbott  E.  Kittredge,  of  Charlestown,  Mass., 
has  accepted  a  call  to  become  pastor  of  this  church.

St.  Paul's  Presbyterian  Church. 
.  Bev.  A.  WiLLi.\.M.«,  Pastor.  This  new  church,

ROMAN    CATHOLIC. 

St.  Mary's  Cathedral. 

Most  Rev.  Joseph  S.  Ai.emanv,  Archbishop; 
Very  Rev.  James  Croke,  V.G.  Rector ;  Rev.  Thomas 
Fagan,  Assistant.  Arcbi-episcopul  and  pastoral  res- 
idence, Dupont  Street,  adjoining  the  Cathedral. 
Location.  NE  corner  California  and  Dupont  streets. 
Masses,  Sundays  at  6|,  9  and  11  o'clock  a.  m.  ;  week 
days,  6,  0^,  7,  and  7^  o'clock  a.  m.  ;  Vespers  at  7 
o'tdock  Sunday  evenings,  in  Winter,  and  7^  in 
Sunnner. 

The  erection  of  this  noble  stiuclure  was  com- 
menced on  the  17th  of  July,  18.33,  durinic  which  year 
the  basement  jjortion  was  built,  and  the  work  was 
resumed  the  July  following.  Dedicated  Dt!ceniber 
S25,  1854.  The  cluirch  is  75  feet  wide,  fronting  on 
California  Street,  by  13]  feet  on  Dupont  Street, 
being  tlie  largest  church  in  the  State.  The  basement 
is  now  used  for  a  school,  at  which  there  is  an  ave- 
rage attendance  of  320  pujjils.  Service  was  begun 
at  midnight  on  December  21,  1854.  Tlie  basement 
portion,  which  is  1!)  feet  high,  is  lighted  from  both 
sides  and  well  ventilated.  The  present  expenditure 
on  tlic  building  is  §175,000.  Tiie  church  portion  is 
45  feet  high  in  the  clear,  and  cofitains  spacious  gal- 
leries and  an  organ  loft.  Tlie  ceilings  are  vaulted 
■with  a  series  of  groined  arches  which  are  decorated 
and  every  means  has  been  resorted  to  for  accommo- 
dation, light,  and  ventilation.  The  cimrch  can  seat 
1,200  persons.  The  lower  is  at  present  135  feet 
high,  and  when  completed,  with  (he  spire,  will 
be  200  feet  high.  The  edilice  is  of  Gothic  archi- 
tecture, which  has  been  carried  out  in  every  detail 
througli  the  building.  In  all  the  arrangements  for 
the  erection  of  the  church,  the  greatest  attention  has 
been  paid  to  the  selection  of  the  best  materials,  and 
to  the  conibiualidu  of  strength  and  dural)ility,  which 
are  admirably  cllocted  in  its  construction."  Craine 
and  England,  architects. 

The  present  dimensions  of  the  Cathedral  not  being 


sufficiently  large  for  the  vast  congrcijaticm  that 
attends  it,  it  is  intended  to  add  about  ibiity  feet  more 
to  its  length,  as  also  an  Archi-episcdoal  and  (lastoral 
residence  on  California  Street,  whicli  will  probably 
be  done  during  the  current  year. 

St.  Francis. 

Rev.  James  S.  Cotter.  Pastor;  Rev.  Thomas 
Cian  (Chinese),  Assistant.  Pastoral  residence  south 
side  Green,  near  Dupont.  Location  north  side  Val- 
lejo  between  Dupont  and  Stockton.  Services,  Sun- 
day 6g,  8J,  and  11  a.  m.  ;  Sunday  School,  2  o'clock 
p.  M.,  and  evening  devotions  at  7  o'clock  p.  M.;  at 
8i  o'clock  A.  M.  the  sermon  is  in  Spanish. 

This  church  was  organized  by  Very  Rev.  Anthony 
Langlois,  in  the  Spring  of  1849,  through  whose 
efforts  a  commodious  frame  building  was  erected  in 
the  month  of  December,  1849,  and  was  the  first 
Roman  Catholic  Church  organized  in  San  Francisco. 
Its  ground  base  was  40  bv  100  feet,  one  story  in 
bight.  During  the  years  l859-'60,  a  large  and  com- 
modious church  was  erected,  which  was  dedicated 
on  the  17th  March,  1860.  Its  design  is  of  the  Gothic 
order,  prevalent  in  the  fourteenth  century,  present- 
ing an  illustration  of  the  Christian  Architecture  of 
that  period.  The  principal  features  of  this  imposing 
structure  are  the  towers,  which  project  beyond  the 
body  of  the  church,  and  present  in  their  elevation 
four  divisions,  rising  to  a  night  of  ninety  feet  from 
the  ground.  "The  entrance  porch,  or  vestibule,  has 
two  side  aisles,  a  semi-octagonal  sanctuary,  and 
two  sacristies,  and  is  approached  by  a  flight  of  ten 
steps,  ascending  to  the  vestibule,  from  which,  at 
each  side,  are  entrances  to  the  galleries  and  bap- 
tistry, and  in  front  are  the  pointed  arched  doorways 
which  lead  to  the  nave  and  aisles.  In  the  central 
space,  between  the  towers,  are  the  three  doorways 
communicating  with  the  vestibule,  and  thence  with 
the  interior.  Over  the  central  door  there  is  a  large 
and  elegant  three-compartment  window,  and  in  the 
gable  a  highly  decorated  rose  window.  Over  each 
side  door  there  is  a  lofty  and  spacious  niche,  which 
rises  from  richly  molded  brick  corbels:  there  are 
also  three  marble  panels,  with  apjivopriale  inscrip- 
tions, recessed  in  the  brick  work  iuuiiediately  over 
the  doorway  and  gable ;  the  work  is  finished  with  a 
massive  ancl  richly  decorated  cross. 

The  east  and  west  sides  of  the  structure  are 
divided  by  buttresses  into  eight  spaces,  in  each 
instance;  seven  of  which  contain  the  large,  pointed, 
arched  windows,  which  light  the  church.  Beneath 
the  flocir  of  till-  rhiirch  there  is  a  large,  well-lighted 
basement,  which  is  used  as  a  school  room,  and  also 
as  a  place  of  meeting  for  the  parishioners.  The 
extreme  length  of  the  building  is  66  by  137  5  feet; 
from  the  floor  to  the  foot  of  the  rafters  is  35  feet. 
The  cost  when  completed  will  be  nearly  $100,000. 

St.  Patrick's  Church. 
Rev.  Pktek  J.  GuEY,  Pastor;  Rev.  Michael 
King,  Assistant.  Location,  south  side  Market 
Street,  between  Second  and  Third  Streets ;  pastoral 
residence.  Market  Street,  adjacent  to  the  church. 
iMasses:  Sundays,  at  6,  8,  and  10  a.  m.,  and  1  p.  m.  ; 
during  the  week,  daily,  at  61  and  7^  a.  m.  ;  evening 
services  at  7^  o'clock.  A  boys'  school  is  kept  in  the 
basement,  at  which  there  is  an  average  attendance 
of  nearly  400  pupils.

St.  Ignatius  Church. 
Rev.  N.  CoNGiATo,  Pastor  ;  Rev.  Fathers  Maras-

chi  and  Bushard,  Assistants.  Location,  north  side

A.  M.  This  church  is  under  the  direction  of  the

Ignatius'  College  connected  with  it.  The  old  build- 
ing being  found  too  small  for  the  rapidly  increiising 
congregation,  the  new  Hall  of  the   College  is  at 

f resent  used  as  a  church,  and  accommodates  about 
,400  persons.  In  the  basement  are  the  school  and 
class  rooms  of  the  College,  and  fronting  on  Market 
Street  the  residence  of  the  Jesuit  Fathers.  The 
church  will  afterward  be  built  on  the  site  of  the  old 
one.  The  present  portion  of  the  institution  recently 
erected  will,  when  completed,  cost  about  $100,000. 

Notre  Dame  des  Victoires. 
Eev.  Father  Molinieh,  Pastor;  Rev.  Father 
Renaud,  Assistant.  Location,  north  side  Bush  be- 
tween Dupont  and  Stockton  streets.  Services  at 
7^  A.  M.  every  day.  Sundaj's  at  7  and  11  a.  m.  ;  also. 
Vespers  at  3^  p.  m.  The  congregation  was  organ- 
ized May,  1856,  and  its  splendid  edilice  dedicated  on 
the  fourth  of  the  same  month.  Tlie  building  was 
constructed  by  a  society  of  Baptists,  and  at  the  date 
above  given  was  disponed  of  to  the  present  owners. 
It  has  a  ground  base  of  50  by  100  feet,  is  a  very 
beautiful  and  massive  brick  structure,  and  with  its 
basement,  which  is  intended  for  school  rooms  con- 
nected with  the  church,  has  a  capacity  of  comfort- 
ably seating  seven  hundred  persons. 

Mission  Dolores. 
Rev.  John  J.  Prendekga.'^t,  Pastor.  Services 
at  8  and  11  o'clock  a.  m.,  on  Sundays  and  Festivals. 
This  adobe  church  is  located  on  tlie  soutli-west  corner 
of  Sixteenth  and  Dolores  streets  ;  lyas  dedicated  on 
the  9th  of  October,  1776,  although  projected  in  1769, 
by  Father  Junipero  Serra,  th^  founder  of  the  Cali- 
fornia Missions.  The  first  Friar  who  had  charge 
was  Francisco  Palou,  who  was  assisted  in  his  labors 
by  Benito  Camboii.  At  the  organization  of  this 
Mission,  and  for  its  protection,  there  were  fifteen 
soldiers  loc  ited  at  the  Presidio,  under  the  command 
of  S.  Flores.  A  cemetery  is  attached  to  the  church, 
in  which  the  first  interment  was  made  in  September, 
1776.  The  first  Indian  convert  was  baptized  on  the 
27th  December  of  the  same  year.  In  the  introduc- 
tory portion  of  the  San  Francisco  Directory  for  1S62, 
page  5,  will  be  found  further  details  connected  with 
the  history  of  this  ^Mission.  Attached  to  this  church 
is  the  Seminary  of  St.  Tliomas. 

St.  Joseph's  Church. 
Rev.  H.  P.  Gallagher,  Pastor;  residence  next 
door  to  the  cli  urch.  Location,  Tenth  Street,  between 
Folsom  and  Howard.  Sen'ices  on  Sundays  and 
Festival  days.  Mass  at  8  o'clock  a.  m.  ;  High  Mass 
at  11  o'clock  a.  m.  ;  Catechism  at  3  and  Vespers  at  7 
o'clock  p.  M. :  Mass,  week  days,  at  7  o'clock  a.  m. 
St.  Joseph's  Church  was  opened  for  divine  service 
on  the  Sth  day  of  December,  1861.  The  building  is 
a  neat  and  substantial  one-story  frame,  60  feet  long 
by  37  feet  wide,  and  stands  on  the  100  vara  lot 
donated  by  Horace  Hawes,  Esq.,  for  the  future 
Cathedral  of  the  Arch  Diocese. 

St.  Hose's  Chtirch. 

Pastor — Vacant.  Attended  from  the  Cathedral. 
Location — Bryant  Street.  Mass :  Sundays,  at  8 
o'clock  A.  M.  St.  Rose's  Church  was  dedicated  on 
the  Festival  of  Pentecost,  June  Sth,  1862.  There  is 
a  vacancy  in  the  Pastorship,  which  will  be  in  a  short 
time  filled.  There  is  connected  with  the  church  a 
school  for  girls,  in  charge  of  the  Sisters  of  St. 
Dominic,  which  contained,  within  one  month  after 
its  establishment,  156  pupils.  There  are  now  more 
than  three  hundred  girls  in  regular  attendance. 


SWEDENBORGIAN. 

New  Jerusalem  Church. 

Public  service  held  every  Sabbath  morning  at  11 
o'clock  A.  M.,  in  the  rooms  of  the  Twellth  District 
Court,  City  Hall.  Administration  of  the  Sacrament 
of  the  Lord's  Supper,  at  the  residence  of  Thomas  S. 
Miller,  823  Bush  Street,  on  the  first  Sundays  of  Janu- 
ary, April,  July,  and  October,  at  2i  o'clock  P.  M. 

This  Society  have  recently  purchased,  at  an  ex- 
pense of  $4, OAO,  a  lot  55  by  137|  feet,  situated  on 
O'Farrell  Street,  between  Mason  and  Taylor,  on 
which  they  intend  to  erect  a  building  for  church 
purposes. 

Officers — Trustees :  Thomas  S.  Miller  (President), 
Joseph  Hobart,  James  Keliogg,  C.  C.  Webb,  T.  C. 
Banks,  Charles  Pace  and  J.  H.  Purkitt;  Reader:  J. 
H.  Pnrkitt;  Librarian:  Dr.  A.  Keliogii;  Sup't  of 
Sabbath  Scliool  and  Treasurer:  James  Kellogg. 

A  library,  containing  all  the  Scientilic  anci  Theo- 
logical works  of  Swedeuborg,  and  a  large  collection 
of  the  collateral  works  of  the  New  Clmrch,  both 
English  and  American,  is  kept  at  Dr.  Kellogg's  Drug 
Store,  517  Jackson  Street,  above  Montgomery. 

The  Chvu-ch  was  organized  in  1851. 


UNITARIAN. 

First  Unitarian  Church. 

Rev.  Thomas  Starr  King,  Pastor.  Location, 
west  side  of  Stockton  Street,  between  Clay  and  Sac- 
ramento. Services  Sunday  at  11  a.  m.  and  7^  p.  m. 
Sabbath  School,  Sunday  at  1  p.  M.  Pastor's  resi- 
dence, No.  831  Bush  Street,  east  of  Taylor.  This 
society  was  organized  September  1,  1850.  The  pre- 
vsent  edifice  owned  by  tlie  societv  was  erected  in 
18.52,  and  dedicated  July  17th,  18.53".  The  first  regu- 
lar Pastor,  the  Rev.  Joseph  Harrington,  arrived 
August  27th,  1852,  and  died  November  2d  of  same 
vear,  of  Panama  fever.  The  second  regular  Pastor, 
iiev.  F.  T.  Gray,  arrived  June,  18.53,  and  left  in 
June,  1854,  and  died  in  Boston  in  February,  1855. 
The  third  regular  Pastor,  the  Rev.  R.  P.  Cutler, 
arrived  August  31,  1854,  and  continued  his  ministra- 
tions without  intermission  until  June  1,  1859,  at 
which  time  he  resigned  his  charge,  and  left  for  New 
York.  The  Rev.  Jno.  A.  Buckingham  then  offici- 
ated as  temporary  Pastor  until  April  5,  1860.  The 
present  Pastor,  "Rev.  T.  S.  King,  arrived  here  with 
ins  family  April  28,  1860,  and  commenced  his  minis- 
trations the  following  day  (Sunday)  before  one  of  the 
largest  congregations  ever  assembled  in  this  city. 
Since  the  commencement  of  Mr.  King's  labors,  and 
during  the  period  of  ten  months,  this  society  relieved 
itself  of  a  debt  which  had  been  for  years  accumu- 
lating upon  them,  and  whicli  amounted  on  the  1st  of 
May,' 1860,  to  very  nearly  *-'0,i)(i().  The  mortgage 
upon  the  building",  $12,500,  has  been  paid,  and  the 
society  is  now  eniirdy  free  from  debt.  The  building 
is  capable  of  seating  1,000  persons,  and  is  one  of  the 
most  attractive  places  of  public  worship  in  the  city. 

Tlie  present  church  edihce  being  inadequate  to  the 
gi-owing  wants  of  this  congregation,  the  society  is 
now  engaged  in  erecting  a  new  building  on  Geary 
Street  below  Stockton. 

As  the  building  will  be  finished  about  the  time  this 
volume  will  be  ready  for  issue,  we  give  a  descrip- 
tion of  it.  The  lot  measures  112^  feet  on  Geary 
Street  by  137 1  feet  in  depth.  On  this  lot  are  erected 
a  church  building  ])roper,  with  a  double  porch  of  ap- 
proach, set  back  twelve  feet  from  the  street,  and  a 
school  building,  set  65  feet  back,  forming  a  wing  to 
the  church  on  the  west  side,  also  approached  from 
Geary  Street.  The  buildings  are  subdivided  into 
accommodations  to  suit  the  needs  and  customs  of  the 
parish  and  the  denomination  to  which  it  belongs. 


504 


SAN    FRANCISCO     DIRECTORY. 


The  auditorium  of  the  chnrcb  edifice  will  contain 
seats  for  1,100  persons,  arriing-edconcentricnlly,  and 
spare  wall  and  other  teats  for  about  100  more.  The 
internal  dimensions  of  the  auditorium  proper,  on  the 
ground  floor,  are  90  feet  by  62.  There  are  galleries 
at  the  sides  and  the  extreme  end.  The  size  of  the 
church  building,  out  and  out  of  the  buttresses,  is  1"28 
feet  by  73,  and  6.5  feet  from  tlie  ground  floor  to  the 
ridge  "of  roof.  The  vestry,  or  school  building,  meas- 
ures 50  feet  by  42  on  plan,  and  4.5  feet  fi-om  ground 
floor  to  ridge.  The  lower  story  of  school  building  is 
14  feet  and  the  upper  16  feet  high.  Tlie  auditorium 
of  the  church  is  35  feet  to  wall-plate,  and  47  feet  to 
center  of  ceiling. 

The  style  of  iu-chitecture  is  Gothic  of  the  15th  cen- 
tury, Cosmopolitan  as  derived  from  the  three  great 
Mediaeval  Schools  of  that  age.  The  form  of  the  ceil- 
ing, through  which  chiefly  the  light  is  admitted,  is  a 
modification  of  the  leading  ideas  of  the  inter-space 
vaulting  of  that  era,  suited  to  the  peculiar  require- 
ments of  the  case.  There  is  a  large  marigold  win- 
dow, 21  feet  in  diameter  at  the  entrance  end  of  the 
auditorium,  with  octo-ramifications  of  tracery,  which 
is  flamboyant  throughout.  There  are  three  great 
arches  at  the  pulpit  end  of  the  auditorium  ;  under 
the  central  one  stands  the  pulpit,  on  the  eastern  side 
a  new  and  powerful  organ  btult  for  the  church  by 
Mr.  Meyer,  of  San  Francisco,  and  on  the  western 
side  the  robing  room,  in  front  of  which  will  stand  a 
massive  baptismal  font.  This  font  is  from  an  im- 
mense blocK  of  Vermont  marble  quarried  for  this 
purpose,  and  presented,  with  all  the  cost  of  carving, 
by  friends  of  the  parish  in  New  York.  It  will  be  sur- 
mounted by  a  gorgeous  cover  of  canopy  and  taber- 
nacle work,  also  a  gift  for  the  ornament  of  the  edifice. 

The  windows  of  stained  glass  are  in  Mosaic.  The 
caiTiets  of  the  church  are  from  patterns  expressly 
designed  for  the  building  by  the  architect,  to  har- 
monize with  the  purposes,  structure,  and  color  of  the 
edifice.  The  exterior  is  massive  and  striking,  sur- 
mounted by  crocketted  pinnacles  on  the  buttresses, 
and  the  interior  promises  to  be  very  rich  and  effective. 
All  the  arrangnients  for  warming  and  ventilating, 
and  for  ingress  and  egress,  are  admiralile.  The 
building  has  been  well  designed  and  f'aitlit'ully  exe- 
cuted. The  corner  stone  was  laid  December  3, 1862, 
with  appropriate  ceremonies.  The  dedication  will  be 
made  probably  about  the  middle  of  October.  The 
edifice  when  finished  and  furnished  will  have  cost, 
with  the  land,  not  far  from  .$75,000.  It  will  be  a 
complete  building  of  the  class  and  type,  and  an 
orminient  to  the  city.  The  architect  is  Mr.  William 
Patton  of  San  Francisco. 

The  original  officers  of  the  Society  were :  F.  W. 
Macondray,  Wm.  Hooper,  S.  P.  Dewey,  Jas.  King 
of  Wm.,  and  F.  A.  Ilussey,  Directors;  George  F. 
Noyes,  Clerk,  and  Jno.  Perry,  jr..  Treasurer. 

Present  OJ/iccrs — R.  ]$.  i>>wain.  Moderator;  W. 
C.  Hinckley,  Treasurer  ;  W.  A.  Maccmdrriy,  Secre- 
tary ;  Wm.  Norris,  J.  ('.  Merrill,  ,1.  A.  Coolidge, 
Chailes  L.  Low,  Edward  Tompkins,  Nathaniel  Page, 
Trustees. 

The  "  Pilgrim  Sunday  School "  connected  with  this 
Society,  has  always  been  one  of  the  largest,  most 
flourisliing,  and  best  conducted  institutions  of  the 
kind  in  this  city.  It  has  a  regular  attendance  of 
about  300,  and  there  is  also  in  cdnncction  with  this 
school  a  valualile  and  increasing  lil)rai'y,  numbering 
at  the  present  time  nearly  3,000  volumes. 


MISCELLANEOUS. 

Chinese  Mission  House. 

Rev.  A.  W.  Loo.Mis,  Pastor;  residence,  north- 
east corner  Stockton  and  Sacramento ;  location, 
north-east  corner  Sacramento  and  Stockton  streets. 


Religious  services  in  the  Chinese  language  on  each 
Sabbath  afternoon  and  evening,  and  also  on  Thurs- 
day evening.  A  day  and  evenmg  school  is  kept 
throughout  the  week.  The  house  is  brick,  and  was 
built  l)y  the  liberality  of  the  citizens  of  San  Fran- 
cisco, and  by  funds  from  a  Board  of  Missions  in 
New  York,  by  which  the  Mission  to  the  Chinese  in 
California  is  supported.  The  hou.se  contains  school 
rooms  in  the  basement ;  on  the  first  floor  a  chapel 
which  will  seat  two  hundred  persons,  and  on  the 
second,  apartments  for  the  accommodation  of  the 
Missionary  family. 

The  Mariners'  Church. 

Rev.  J.  RouELT,,  Pastor;  resdence,  on  Bernard 
Street,  near  Tavlor;  location,  Clark  Street  near 
Pacific  Wharf. 

This  church  was  organized  with  six  members,  in 
December,  1S58,  and  now  consists  of  seventy-five. 
Public  worship  every  Sabbath  at  3  o'clock  p.  m. 
There  is  connected  with  the  Church  a  Sabbath 
School  and  Bible  Class,  numbering  more  than  ninety 
teachers  and  scholars.  The  house  of  worship  is  a 
commodious  wooden  building,  on  Clark  Street,  near 
Drumm.  It  was  erected  some  years  since  by  con- 
tributions from  merchants  a;id  other  citizens  of  San 
Francisco. 

Officers — Rev.  J.  Rowell,  Pastor  and  Chaplain  of 
the  American  Seaman's  Friend  Society,  who  has 
labored  here  since  August,  1858;  Obed  Chart.  James 
F.  Stewart  and  Henry  Chester,  Deacons. 

This  Chnrch  finds  a  wide  field  of  usefulness,  in 
the  usual  Church  services,  a  large  Bible  Class  for 
seamen  and  strangers,  a  Sabbath  religious  reading 
room,  weekly  prayer  meetings  in  several  sailors' 
boarding  houses,  preaching  on  the  Sabbath  and  per- 
sonal lafior  during  tjie  week  at  the  U.  S.  Marine 
Hospital,  ili.'<(i<^)jJtioniof  feibles  and  tracts  on  ship 
board  lioaiiliiig^^ious®;  aifd  elsewhere,  and  mission- 
ary labors  about  tli,^streets,  wharfs,  and  shipping, 
and  on  board  several  men-of-war,  and  other  sea- 
going A'essels.  It  is  an  undenominational  missionary 
church. 

During  the  year  1860  a  society  was  fomied  among 
the  business  men  of  San  Francisco,  having  for  its 
object  the  moral  improvement  of  seamen,  called  the 
San  Francisco  Port  Society.  It  seeks  to  attain  its 
object  by  sustaining  the  preaching  of  the  Gospel, 
and  other  missionary  labors,  in  connection  with  the 
Mariners'  Church.  The  officers  of  the  Society  for 
the  present  year,  are  :  Ira  P.  Rankin,  President ;  R. 

B.  Swain,  Vice  President;  J.  Rowell,  Secretary;  A. 

C.  Nichols,  Treasurer;  Dr.  H.  P.  Coon,  Capt.'J.  B. 
Thomas,  A.  C.  Nichols,  Nathaniel  Gray,  J.  F.  Pope, 
Cyrus  Palmer,  Louis  McLane,  J.  Rowell,  and  James 
F.  Stewart,  Trustees.

nary south  side  Stevenson  near  Second.  Sunday

Organized  April,  1851.  The  present  building  was 
erected  in  1854,  at  a  cost  of  $35,000  ;  it  is  a  noble

CALIFORNIA  BIBLE  SOCIETY.— Organized 
October  30,  1849,  with  John  M.  Finley  as  President ; 
and  the  Reverends.!.  L.  VerMehr,  Albert  Williams, 
W.  Taylor,  Vice  Presidents ;  and  T.  D.  Hunt  as 
Secretary.  Office  757  Mai-ket  Street.  Meetings  of 
the  Boai-d  of  Trustees  are  held  by  appointment  on 
the  Tuesday  after  the  first  Sunday  of  each  month. 
The  first  buihling  of  the  Society,  on  Stockton  Street, 
was  destroyed  by  fire  April  20,  18.53,  when  a  new 
one  was  erected  on  the  same  site  at  an  expense  of 
$7,000.  The  corner  stone  of  the  new  building  of 
the  Society,  757  Market  Street,  was  laid  with  appro- 
priate ceremonies  on  the  second  day  of  May,  1862. 
The  edifice  is  an  omament  to  the  city,  a  marked 
feature  of  the  enterprise  and  foresight  of  the  Boai'd 
of  Trustees  ;  having  disposed  of  the  property  owned 
by  the  Society  on  Montgomery  Street,  they  selected 
this  location  on  a  growing  thoroughfare,  in  hopes 
that  the  future  income  of  the  property  will  enable 
the  respected  agent.  Rev.  V.  Buel,  to  more  fully 
extend  the  circulation  of  the  IIolv  Scriptures  in  this 
State,  and  the  Pacific  Coast.  The  building  is  50 
feet  by  75,  three  stories,  with  stores  on  the  ground 
floor.  One  of  them  is  now  occupied  as  the  deposi- 
tory of  the  Society.  The  name  of  the  Society  was 
changed  by  Act  of  the  Legi.'ilature,' 1859,  from  the 
San  Francisco  Bible  Society  to  its  present  title. 
New  Constitution  adopted  November,  1860. 

O^Ver.s— President :  Rev.  J.  T.  Peck,  D.D.;  Vice 
Presidents:  Reverends  A.  Williams,  I).  B.  Cheney, 
S.  H.  Willey,  S.  D.  Simmonds,  F.  M.  McAllister,  J. 
Rowxll,  all  of  San  Francisco;  Rev.  M.  C.  Briggs, 
Santa  Clara  ;  Rev.  W.  C.  P(md,  Downieville  ;  Rev. 
Lucius  Hamilton,  San  Jos6 :  Revds.  W.  H.  Hill  and 
J.  A.  Benton,  Sacramento ;  Rev.C.  C.  Pierce,  Placer- 


ville;  Rev.  J.  W.  Ross,  Yreka ;  Hon.  D.  O.  Shat- 
tuck,  and  Hon.  H.  P.  Coon,  San  Francisco;  Rev. 
John  Braley,  Santa  Clara  ;  Rev.  Isaac  Owen,  Sacra- 
mento ;  Rev.  Peter  Veder,  Napa  ;  Treasurer :  C. 
Wittram ;  Secretary :  William  R.  Wad.sworth.  Depo- 
sitory, 757  Market ;  Agent :  Rev.  F.  Buel. 

SABBATH  SCHOOL  UNION.— Reorganized 
May,  1857.  The  Union  meets  monthly,  alternately 
at  the  different  churches  whose  schools  are  repre- 
sented in  the  Union,  when  reports  from  the  different 
schools,  showing  the  average  attendance  of  scholars 
and  teachers  for  the  previous  month,  are  presented. 
(See  General  Review.) 

Officers — President :  W.  H.  Codington,  Howard 
Street  Methodist  Episcopal  Church.  Vice  Presidents : 
Benjamin  T.  Martin,  First  Baptist  Church  ;  Franklin 
Tutiiill,  First  Congregational  Church  ;  E.  W.  Plater, 
Powell  Street  Methodist  Episcopal  Church  ;  C.  L. 
Kellogg,  First  Presbyterian  Church  ;  John  Reynold, 
Second  Baptist  Church  ;  and  Joseph  Mysell,  Mission 
Street  German  Church.  Secretary  and  Treasurer : 
Chester  Snow. 

SAN  FRANCISCO  TRACT  SOCIETY.— Aux- 
iliary to  American  Tract  Society  ;  Depository  at  C. 
Beach's  Book  Store,  34  Montgomery  Street  near 
Sutter.    Organized  August  16th,  1852. 

Officers — President :  Rev.  J.  Rowell ;  Secretary  : 
Thomas  B.  Ludluni;  Treasurer:  J.  K.  S.  Latham; 
and  a  Board  of  Directors  composed  of  one  delegate 
from  each  Evangelical  Church  in  the  City. 

SAN  FRANCISCO  PORT  SOCIETY.— Organ- 
ized March,  1860. 

Officers — President:  Ira  P.  Rankin;  Vice  Presi- 
dent: R.  B.  Swain;  Secretary  :  J.  Kovvell ;  Treas- 
urer: A.  C.  Nichols  ;  Trustees:  A.  C.  Nichols,  O.  B. 
Jennings,  Louis  McLane,  J.  B.  Thomas,  Nathaniel 
Gray,  Cyrus  Palmer,  J.  Rowell,  J.  F.  Pope,  and 
James  F.  Stewart. 

The  object  of  the  Society  is  the  moral  improve- 
ment of  seamen,  and  others  connected  with  the  sea, 
in  this  port,  by  aiding  the  American  Seamen's  Friend 
Society  of  New  York  in  sustaining  the  Mariners' 
Churcli  of  San  Francisco,  and  in  such  enterprises 
connected  therewith  as  the  Society  may  approve. 
This  Society  is  organized  and  sustained  on  the  prin- 
ciple that  it  belongs  propei-ly  to  the  people  of  San 
Francisco  to  provide  religious  privileges  and  instruc- 
tion for  the  sailors  belonging  to  and  yiwitiug  this  port. 
Any  person  may  become  a  member  by  paying  $5  a 
vear,  or  a  life  member  by  the  payment  at  one  tmie 
of  $50. 

SONS  OF  TEMPERANCE.— Office  of  the  Grand 
Scribe,  No.  410  Montgomery  Street,  room  No.  7. 
Annual  Session  Grand  Division  held  at  San  Fran- 
cisco, fourth  Tuesday  in  October,  1863.

PARENT  DASHAWAY  ASSOCIATION.— Or- 
ganized January  .3d,  ]859.  Number  of  members 
who  have  joined  the  Association  since  that  date, 
5,400.  The  Society  occupy  their  new  and  commo- 
dious building  on  Post  Street  near  Dupont,  built  by 
the  Association  at  a  cost,  including  lot,  of  $2!2,000, 
one-half  of  which  debt  has  been  liquidated  up  to  the 
present  time.  Public  meetings  are  held  on  Sunday 
afternoons  and  Sunday  and  Thursday  evenings. 
Business  meeting,  Tuesday  evening. 

Officers — President:  Franklin  L.  Jones ;  First  Vice

Wm.  Windsor,  and  Jas.  A.  J.  Bohen. 

HOME  FOR  THE  CARE  OF  THE  INEBRI- 
ATE.—Organized  May  24,  1859.  The  Society  have 
recently  purchased  the  property  known  as  Pfeiffer's 
Building,  north-east  corner  Stockton  and  Chestnut, 
at  an  expense  of  $7,500. 

Officers — Trustees :  Frank  G.  Edwards,  J.  T.

J.  O.  Eldridge,  Michael  Noonian,  Rev.  T.  Starr 
King,  and  Rev.  W.  J.  Maclay  ;  Superintendent : 
John  Armiti'.ge;  Matron:  Mrs.  John  Armitage. 

The  Legislature  of  the  State,  at  the  last  session, 
authorized  the  Board  of  Supervisors  to  appropriate 
$250  per  month  for  the  support  of  this  institution.

YOUNG  MEN'S  CHRISTIAN  ASSOCIATION. 

— Established  in  18.53,  having  for  its  object  the 
moral,  socinl,  and  intellectual  improvement  of  young 
men  of  all  denominations,  by  means  of  a  Reading 
Room  supplied  with  all  the  leading  religious  and 
secular  papers,  magazines,  and  periodicals  domestic 
and  foreign,  together  with  a  well  selected  Library 
of  more  than  2,000  volumes.  (See  Historical  and 
General  Review.) 

The  third  Monday  evening  of  each  month  is  de- 
voted to  literary  exercises  and  debates,  open  to  all. 
A  Prayer  Sleeting,  to  which  all  of  every  denomina- 
tion are  welcome,  is  held  at  the  Rooms  every  Satur- 
day evening  from  8  to  9  o'clock. 

The  Rooms  of  the  Association  are  at  629  (old  No. 
171 1)  Washington  Street,  nearly  opposite  the  Opera 
House,  which  are  open  the  year  round  from  8  a.  m. 
to  10  p.  M.  The  Library  is  open  every  day  (Sundays 
excepted)  from  3  to  10  p.  m. 

Officers — President :  H.  L.  Chamberlain ;  Vice 
Presidents:  J.  T.  Bowers,  M.  B.  French,  C.  W. 
Amies,  G.  H.  Bell,  R.  G.  Davidson  ;  Recording  Sec- 
retary :  James  M.  Philbrook  ;  Corresponding  .Secre- 
tary :  Elijah  Clough ;  Treasurer :  Ralph  C.  Harri- 
.son ;  Librarian :  .James  L.  Cogswell ;  Board  of 
Managers:  C.  J.  King,  J  H.  Purdy,  Geo.  T.  Haw- 
ley,  John  Lowry,  W.  F.  Kellett,  George  L.  Plymp- 
ton,  A.  P.  Wade,  Jacob  Bacon,  Wm.  M.  Cubery, 
John  Kiloh,  Wm.  Krug,  James  F.  Stewart,  and 
Chas.  Spencer ;  Registrar :  Thaddeus  Hanford.

ORPHA#  .aJPlUM  (CATHOLIC).— Market 
near  Kearny '  ^reet.  Organized  March  23,  1851, 
and  placed  under  the  care  of  the  Sisters  of  Charity. 
A  frame  building  for  this  purpose  wa.s  commenced 
in  July,  and  completed  in  September,  1851.  It  was 
occupied  in  part  lor  a  school,  and  a  portion  was  tem- 
porarily used  as  a  church,  under  the  pastoral  charge 
of  Rev.  John  Maginnis.  The  present  capacious 
brick  building  was  completed  in  November,  1854,  at 
a  cost  of  $45,000.  It  is  a  source  of  gratification  to 
behold  the  consoling  appearance  presented  by  the 
320  little  ones  now  provided  for  in  tlir  institution, 
which  speaks  audibly  of  the  benign  intlufnce  of  their 
guardian  Sisters,  and  of  the  true  liberality  of  our  com- 
munity in  their  noble  efforts  to  lend  a  helping  hand 
to  the  fatherless.  Another  spacious  brick  building 
of  the  same  dimensions  as  that  erected  in  1854,  was 
completed  in  January,  18.59,  for  a  school,  in  which 
550  children,  day  scholars,  receive  a  useful  educa- 
tion. The  Asylum  is  coiulucteil  under  the  sole  man- 
agement of  Archbishop  Aleniany,  Rev.  John  Magin- 
nis, and  the  Sisters  of  Charity. 

A  farm  of  fifty-three  acres  has  been  purchased  at 
Hunter's  Point,  where  a  branch  Orphan  Asylum  has 
been  established  for  very  young  children.  '  A  large 
and  commodious  brick  edifice  will  soon  be.  erected 
thereon. 

SAN  FRANCLSCO  ORPHAN  ASYLUM  SO- 
CIETY (PROTESTANT).  — Oiganized  January 
31,  1851,  and  incorporated  February  10,  1851.

owned  by  Mr.  H.  W.  Halleck,  whence  they  re- 
moved the  children  in  March,  1854,  to  the  present 
building,  just  then  completed  at  a  cost  of  $30,000. 
This  house,  built  of  stone  and  brick,  expressly  for 
the  purpose,  is  highly  creditable  to  the  Institution, 
and  one  of  the  noblest  luoiiuments  of  San  Frumisc-o 
benevolence.  During  the  year  IStW-'ti:},  a  large  ami 
convenient  addition  was  made  to  the  present  l)uilil- 
ing,  at  an  expense  of  $30,000,  which,  together  with 
the  main  building,  will  accommodate  250  children. 
As  a  compliment  to  the  Sansom  Hook  and  Ladder 
Co.,  who.  upon  disbanding,  donated  to  the  Asylum 
the  building  and  lot  owned  by  them,  the  new  addi- 
tion is  called  the  "  Sansom  Wing."  The  number  of 
childien  under  the  care  of  the  Asylum  is  95,  of  which 
52  are  boys,  and  43  girls.

SOCIATION (colored).— Organized  February,  1863.

of  each  month.     Number  of  members  30.

CHEBRA  ACHIM  RACHMONIM  ASSOCIA- 
TION.—Organized  October  2(7th,  1862.  Meetings 
held  in  Piatt's  Hall  the  third  Sunday  of  each  month. 
Number  of  members,  60.  Their  object  is  to  relieve 
and  care  for  the  sick,  infirm  and  disabled  members 
of  the  Society,  etc.  The  funds  and  property  of  the 
Society  are  to  constitute  a  Charitv  Fund,  in  which 
no  member  will  have  an  individual  interest. 

Officers — President:  Nathan  Levy;  Vice  Presi- 
dent: William  Saalburg;  Recording  Secretary:  S. 
Danielreveiz ;  Financial  Secretary  :  J.  W  Manasse.

CHINESE  BENEVOLENT  ASSOCIATION. 
— Established  1862.  Sustained  by  the  Hop  Wo 
Company,  707  Commercial  Street.  The  object  of 
this  Association  is  to  assist  Chinese  coming  to  this 
State  ;  to  assist  them  when  desiring  to  return  to 
China;  to  minister  to  the  sick,  bury  the  dead,  and 
return  their  corpses  to  their  native  land.

FRENCH  BENEVOLENT  SOCIETY,  (Soci^e 
Fran^aise  de  Bienfaisance  Mutuelle). — Established 
December  28th,  1851.  This  is  a  Mutual  Relief  Soci- 
ety, established  for  the  purpose  of  atibrding  assist- 
ance to  its  members  in  case  of  sickness.  The  build- 
ings at  present  connected  with  the  Society  are  loca- 
ted on  the  corner  of  Bush  and  Taylor.  A  new  and 
commodious  hospital  has  been  recently  erected  on 
Bryant  Street,  between  Fifth  and  Sixth,  which 
forms  a  very  important  addition  to  the  charitable 
institutions  of  the  city.  Office  of  the  Society,  649 
Sacramento  Street.
