GER^MAN  GENERAL  BENEVOLENT  SO- 
CIETY OF  SAN  FRANCISCO  (styled  in  German, 
Die  Allgenieine  Deutsche  Unterstuetzungs  Gesell- 
schaft),  is  one  of  the  largest  and  most  efficient  chari- 
table associations  in  the  State.  It  was  organized  on 
the  ("th  of  .lanuary,  1854,  with  10.5  members,  and 
has  rajiidly  increased  until  now  it  numbers  1,200 
city  members,  and  400  in  the  interior. 

Only  Germans  and  persons  speaking  German  are 
admitted  to  membership.  The  chief  purpose  of  the 
association  is  mutual  assistance  in  case  of  sickness, 
and  when  sick,  every  member  has  a  right  to  demand 
support  and  medical  attendance  from  the  Society. 
The  Society  has  a  second  purpose  of  doing  charity 
to  Germans  not  members  of  the  association,  and 
especiiiUy  to  German  immigrants  newly  arrived. 
The  Society  has  a  hospital  situated  in  Brannan  Street 
near  Third,  built  of  brick,  two  stories  high,  with  a 
basement,  112^  feet  front,  50  feet  deep,  with  a  wing- 
in  the  rear  of  23  feet  front,  122  feet  deep,  furnished 
with  steam,  sulphur,  hot  and  cold  water  and  shower 
baths,  and  other  conveniences  for  the  treatmaJlfcpf 
the  sick.  The  wards  are  smaller  than  in  any 
hospital  in  the  city,  so  that  not  many  patieni 
nut  together  in  a  room.  The  lot  upon  which  the 
nospital  is  built  is  137  feet  6  inches  wide  by  275  feet 
long,  the  whole  surrounded  by  a  high  fence  and 
cultivated  in  a  fine  garden,  a  part  planted  with  orna- 
mental flowers  and  shrubs  and  a  part  with  kitchen 
vegetables.  The  property  of  the  society,  including 
the  lot  and  hos|)ilal  buildings,  is  worth  about  $36,500, 
and  the  debts  amount  to  about  ^7,000.  The  revenue 
of  the  society  amounted  in  1861  to  about  $20,000, 
derived  chiefly  from  a  monthly  assessment  of  $1 
levied  on  each  member.  The  expenses  of  the  hospital 
in  the  year  1861  amounted  to  22,219  90,  of  wnich 
$9,703  "65  were  paid  by  the  Society  and  $12,516  25 
by  paying  patients.  In  the  year  1861  the  hospital 
received  517  patients,  of  whom  372  were  members, 
52  non-members,  and  93  paying  patients.  During 
the  last  seven  years  399  persons,  non-members  of 
tlie  association  were  received  in  the  hosi)ital  out  of 
charity,  and  maintained  by  the  association  during 
!(l,79.jHi(:k  days  in  all,  and  an  expense  of  $19,034. 
Tlic  Society  has  iis  paid  servants  in  the  hospital,  a 
superintendent,  an  apothecary,  a  gardener,  a  cook, 
and  five  waitere.  The  present  officers  of  the  Society 
are  : 

President :  C.  F.  Mebius :  Vice  President :  Jacob 
Gundhich  ;  Recording  Secretary  :  M.  Bornheim  ; 
Financial  Secretary  :  Theodore  llelmkcn  ;  Treas- 
urer :  H.  Nielsen;  Directors:  E.  A.  Engelberg,  H. 
Kenitzer,  A.  H.  Siegfried,  H.  I'lluger,  J.  C.  Meusf- 
dorffer,  F.  Tillmann,  Chs.  Falirl)ach  ;  Physicians : 
Drs.  Loehr,  Regensberger,  and  Scharlach. 

The  office  of  Uie  Society  is  at  625  Merchant  Street, 
between  Montgomery  and  Kearny  streets,  where 
the  principal  agent,  .Julius  Barkhiiusen,  can  be  found 
from  8  to  12  A.  M.,  and  from  2  to  5  i>.  m.,  on  week 
days.  All  applications  for  admission  into  the  society, 
or  for  charitable  relief,  and  to  furnish  employment, 
or  servants  U)  applicants,  should  be  addressed  to  the 
agent.    No  charge  for  applications. 


HEBREW  SELF-PROTECTING  ASSOCIA- 
TION.—Organized  July,  1863.  This  is  a  charitable 
and  benevolent  society,  organized  under  the  laws  of 
the  State  concerning  corporations.  The  objects  and 
purposesof  the  Association  are  to  suppoitthe  afflicted, 
to  relieve  the  distressed,  to  attend  to  tlie  dying,  and 
to  bury  the  dead  of  the  members  of  the  society. 
The  funds  and  j)roperty  ai'e  to  constitute  a  charity 
fund,  in  which  no  member  shall  have  an  individual 
interest,  and  shall  be  disbursed  in  carrying  out  the 
objects  and  purposes  of  the  society.  Tlie  time  of 
the  existence  of  the  society  shall  be  fifty  years. 

Officers — Trustees  :  Joseph  Wolfson,  S.  Goldberg, 
S.  H.  Shocken,  W.  H.  Krause,  Isadore  Charles,  S. 
Liebreicb,  L.  Watters,  M.  Fuchs,  J.  Gosliver,  and 
R.  Prag.

LADIES  PROTECTION  AND  RELIEF  SO- 
CIETY.—Established  August  4,  18.53.  Incorporated 
August  9,  1854.  The  object  of  this  Society  shall  be 
to  render  protection  and  assistance  to  strangers,  to 
sick  and  dependent  women.  This  Society  has  under 
its  supervision  a  Home — 23  Tehama  Street,  between 
First  and  Second — where  information,  protection, 
and  aid,  will  be  aftbrded  to  women  and  children, 
residents  or  strangers.

LADIES   SEAMEN'S   FRIEND   SOCIETY.— 

Organized  March  26th,  1856.  This  Society  is  the 
o!t■-^;p^ing  of  the  great  philanlhropical  movement  on 
behalf  of  seamen  which  has  peculiarly  distinguished 
the  last  half  century.  The  "men  of  the  sea,'  an 
invaluable  class,  to  all  mercantile  countries,  are  sub- 
jected, by  the  nature  of  their  avocations,  to  hardship 
and  deprivation,  moral,  social,  and  intellectual.  To 
ameliorate  their  condition  by  supplying  them  vyith  a 
Home,  when  on  shore,  surniiuHleil,  by  reiiie(lial  in- 
fluences, and  affording  them  prolect ion  from  iuiposi- 
tiou  is  the  object  of  the  Society. 

Their  present  "  Sailor's  Home,"  is  situated  at  the 
corner  of  Vallejo  and  Battery  streets.  Capt.  James 
F.  Stewart.  Superintendent ;  Albert  Worth,  Chaplain. 
Officers—  First  Directiess  :  Mrs.  Williamson  ; 
Second  Directress:  Mrs.  M.  N.  Thurston;  Corres-

MAGDALEN  ASYLUM.— Under  the  charge  of 
the  Sisters  of  Mercv.  The  asvlum  occupies  an  ex- 
tensive building  80  feet  long  "by  30  feet  wide,  and 
three  stories  in  Bight,  erected  at  an  expense  of  $7,500. 
Since  the  opening  of  the  institution  about  seventy  fe- 
males have  been  received,  most  of  whom  have  been 
reformed.  There  are  at  present  about  thirty  inmates, 
who  are  employed  at  embroidery,  needle  work,  etc., 
in  order  to  aid  in  the  support  of  the  institution.  The 
last  Legislature  appropriated  $3,000  toward  its  main- 
tenance.   Location,  Hayes  Park.

STATE  DEAF,  DUMB,  AND  BLIND  ASSO- 
CIATION. —  Located  corner  of  Mis.sion  and  Fif- 
teenth streets.  Organized  1860.  Number  of  pupils, 
39,  of  which  17  are  blind.  The  total  appropriations 
by  the  State  of  California  to  the  first  of  January, 
1863,  toward  the  building  of  the  institution,  amount 
to  $20,000.  The  appropriation  by  the  city  of  San 
Francisco  toward  the  purchase  and  improvement 
of  the  lots  upon  which  the  buildings  are  erected 
amounts  to  $7,000.  About  $2,000  derived  from  pri- 
vate charity  have  been  expended  upon  furniture  and 
necessary  fixtures.  The  present  value  of  the  build- 
ings and  grounds  is  estimated  at  $42,000.  At  pres- 
ent the  institution  is  under  the  charge  and  control  of 
the  Lady  Managers,  who  are  ready  to  receive  all 
children  of  this  unfortunate  class.    Among  all  the 


510 


SAN  FRANCISCO  DIRECTORY. 


cbixritable  institutionp  so  liberally  sustained  by  the 
wealthy  and  benevolent,  none  is  more  worthy  of 
support  thnn  this.  The  school  will  be  free  to  all ; 
yet  it  is  expected  of  jtarenta  and  guardians  of  chil- 
clren,  who  nave  the  ability,  to  pay  SWO  per  annum  ; 
an  allowance  of  ^'^^O  for  each  pupil  is  provided  for 
by  Legislative  enactment. 

"The  Managers  propose  to  receive  all  of  suitable 
age  to  commence  their  education,  and  it  is  consid- 
ered better  to  send  the  deaf  mutes  young,  say  five 
years  old,  as  it  is  essential  they  should  learn  the 
Sign  language  correctly  at  the  commencement. 

The  Legislature  of  the  State,  at  the  session  of 
1863,  p;i!-scd  an  act  sul)mitting  to  the  people  of  the 
State,  an  act  authorizing  the  issue  of  State  bonds  to 
the  amount  of  $75,01  lO  for  the  completion  and  fur- 
nishing of  this  institution.  The  question  was  decided 
in  the  affirmative  by  a  large  majority,  and  the  com- 
ing year  will  witness,  no  doubt,  the  completion  of 
one  "of  the  most  praiseworthy  undertakings  on  this 
coast. 

C>/?;Ve/-.5  —  President :  Mrs.  P.  B.  Clark;  Vice 
President :  Mrs.  J.  P.  Whitney  ;  Treasurer :  Mrs.  B. 
H.  Randolph;  Secretary:  Mrs.  O.  C.  Pratt. 

ST.  JOSEPH'S  BENEVOLENT  SOCIETY  (R. 

C.) — Established  1860.  The  objects  of  this  society 
are  to  extend  assistance  to  each  other  in  the  time  of 
sickness,  by  corporeal  aid  and  spiritual  consolation  ; 
for  providing  their  deceat^ed  l)retliren  with  a  decent 
and  christian  interment  in  accordance  with  their 
Holy  Faith  ;  for  the  relief  of  the  families  they  may 
leave  after  them  ;  as  also  for  stimulating  each  other 
to  a  more  constant  observance  of  the  duties  of  relig- 
ion and  the  general  promotion  of  moral  and  iutel 
lectual  improvement. 

Officers — Pi  e.'<ident :  Matthew   McClusk^ 
President :  Michael  Kane  ;  Secretary  :  J   ~ 
Chaplain  :  Rev.   M.  King  ;  Treasurer  :  M 
Meetings  held  third  Suncfay  of  each  mont  ^ 
basement  of   St.   Mary's   Cathedral.      Num 
members,  135. 

ST.  MARY'S  LADIES'  SOCIETY.— Adjoinmg 
St.  JIary's  Hospital  is  St.  Mary's  Hall,  a  wooden 
building  60  by  30  feet,  erected  by  the  St.  i\Iary's 
Ladies'  Society  for  their  meetings.  St.  Mary's  So- 
ciety, which  was  founded  by  the  Sisters  of  Mercy, 
1859,  for  the  purpose  of  promoting  piety  among  the 
Catholic  females,  has  within  the  last  year  been  con- 
verted into  a  Mutual  ]>eiicvolent  Society.  It  num- 
bers between  live  and  six  hundred  members.  The 
olficers  of  the  Society  are  selected  from  the  Sisters 
of  ]\Iercy.     Chaplain  :  Rev.  Michael  King.

WAITERS'  UNION  BENEVOLENT  SOCIE- 
TY.—Orgaui/.cd  .Inly  -id,  1863.  Meetings  held  at 
Metroiiolitau  ll:dl  the  Hist  and  third  Monday  even- 
ing of  each  UKjnth.  Number  of  members,  300.  The 
object  of  this  union  is  the  maintenance  of  a  fair 
rate  of  wages,  the  encoiu'agement  of  good  work- 
men, the  prompt  payment  of  their  earnings,  and  to 
prevent  all  persons"  in  their  line  of  business  from 
working  for  less  than  the  established  rates  of  wages  ; 
a  charitable  regard  for  the  sick  and  disabled,  and 
the  btu'ial  of  the  dead. 

Officers — President :  James  McKew  ;  Vice  Presi-

SCHKDrLF,  11.— Rales  of  Storage  on  Merchandise. 
Measurement  goods,  per  month,  $1  per  ton  of  forty  cubic 
feet;  heavy  ditto,  $1  per  ton  of  2,000  lbs;  or,  in  cither 
case  the  amount  actually  paid.  Tlie  consignee  to  have  tlie 
option  of  charging  by  weight  or  measurement.  A  fraction 
of  a  month  to  be  charged  as  a  month. 

Regulations.—  Concerning  delivery  of  Merchandise,  pay- 
ment of  Freight,  etc. : 

When  no  express  stipulation  exists  per  bill  of  lading, 
goods  are  to  be  considered  as  deliverable  on  shore. 

Freight  on  all  goods  to  be  paid,  or  secured  to  the  satis- 
faction of  the  captain  or  consignee  of  the  vessel,  prior  to 
the  delivery  of  the  goods. 

Alter  the  delivery  to  the  purchaser  of  merchandise  sold, 
no  claims  for  damage,  deficiency,  or  other  cause,  shall  be 
admissable  uiik'ss  made  within'  three  days,  and  no  such 
claim  sliall  be  :uhiii-sable  after  goods  sold  and  delivered 
have  ..lu-c  Iclt  the  rity. 

When  loreiyn  bills  of  lading  do  not  expressly  stipulate 
the  payment  of  freight  in  a  specific  coin,  foreigri  cnn-ency 
shall  be  reckoned  according  to  the  United  States  value 
thereof,  and  pavment  may  be  made  in  any  legal  tender  of 
the  United  .States. 

Where  lorei;.;n  bills  of  lading  expressly  stipulate  that  the 
freight  shall  be  paid  in  a  specific  coin,  then  the  same  must 
be  procured,  if  required,  or  its  equivalent  given— the  rate 
to  be  determined  bj'  the  cuiTent  value  at  the  time  in  San 
Francisco. 

For  tare  on  China  Sugar  4  lbs.  is  to  be  allowed  on  each 
mat  containing  4  pockets  of  about  25  lbs.  each. 

All  other  rates  of  tare  are  to  be  allowed  as  by  custom 
in  Js'ew  York,  except  when  other^^jse prfcjded

Russell,  Christopher  Flood,  and  John  Savason. 

SAN  FRANCISCO  ARCHITECTURAL  SO- 
CIETY.— Organized  1861.  Office  Metropolitan 
Block.  The  object  of  the  Society  is  to  promote  and 
preserve  the  artistic,  scientific,  and  practical  know- 
ledge of  its  members ;  to  facilitate  their  intercourse 
and  good  fellowship  ;  to  elevate  the  standing  and 
sustain  the  dignity  of  the  sublime  profess^ion,  and  to 
unite  the  efforts  of  those  engaged  in  the  i>ractice  of 
Architecture,  for  the  general  advanceiiient  of  the 
truthful  art.  The  means  of  accomplishing  this  end 
are:  regular  nyBtings  of  the  members  for  the  pro- 

(otion  of  harm(»^  oj|action,  the  discussion  of  sub- 
cts  <•  •)i<>lfst^kaAimJJortance,  the  reading  of 
jSayiJpwl  oiii^Bl^kpers,  lectures  on  topics  of 
merariuterestj^B  library,  a  collection  of  designs 
and  models,  aiid^ny  oilier  means  calculated  by  the 
Society  to  promote  the  objects  of  its  organization.

SAN  FRANCISCO  SAVINGS  UNION.— In- 
corporated June  18th,  1862. 

Offi cer  s  —  President :  James  DeFremery ;  Vice 
President :  Albert  Miller ;  Directors  :  Washington 
Bartlett,  John  P.  Buckley,  Charles  L.  Taylor,  Ed- 
ward P.  Flint,  Charles  Pace,  and  James  Bowman; 
Cashier  and  Secretary  :  John  Archbald. 

This  association  otters  to  the  public  a  secure  depo- 
sitory for  small  savings,  and  facilities  for  obtainmg 
loans  on  real  estate,  on  terms  very  advantageous  to 
those  wishing  to  procure  homesteads  of  moderate 
value.  Security  is  insured  to  its  depositors  by  a  cash 
capital,  paid  in  by  its  stockholders,  which,  under 
the  statute  can  in  no  case  be  withdrawn  until  all  its 
liabilities  are  discharged,  even  though  this  should 
exhaust  every  dollar  both  of  the  Capital  and  of  the 
Reserved  Fund.  The  statute  also  positively  pro- 
hibits any  purchase  or  investment  which  would 
bring  the  corporation  into  debt.  Office  513  Califor- 
nia Street. 

SAVINGS  AND  LOAN  SOCIETY.— Incorpo- 
rated July  23d,  1857. 

Officers  —  President:  E.  W.  Burr;  Vice  Presi- 
dent :  Benjamin  D.  Dean  ;  Auditor  ^ James  O.  Deau  ; 
Secretary  :  William  F.  Herrick  ;  zAttorneyr  Gile^ 
H.  Gray  ;  Surveyor  :  GardueifEll&t-  '  *  i 

The  object  for  which  this  Socrety  is  formed,  i^ 
that  by  means  of  it  the  members  may  be  enabled  to 
find  a  secure  and  profitable  investment  for  small 
savings.  Deposits  received  from  two  and  a  half 
dollars  up  to  any  amount.  Deposits  are  invested  in 
mortgages  of  real  estate.  Amount  of  capital  paid 
in,  nearly  $2,000,000,  invested  exclusively  on  first 
bond  and  mortgage.  The  society  have  recently 
erected,  for  the  accommodation  of  their  increasing 
business,  a  fine  three-story  brick  building,  619  Clay 
Street.

SOCIETY  OF   CALIFORNIA  PIONEERS.— 

Organized  in  August,  1850.  Rooms  north-east  cor- 
ner of  Montgomery  and  Gold  streets,  near  Jackson. 
Officers  for  the  year  commencing  July  7,  1863. —

of  San  Francisco ;  James  Lick  of  Santa  Clai-a,  J.  P. 


514 


SAN    FRANCISCO     DIRECTORY. 


Leese  of  Monterey,  J.  C.  Birdseye  of  Nevada;  Sec- 
retary :  Win.  L.  Ihnican  ;  Treasurer  :  John  H.  Tiir- 
ney ;'Mar8lial:  A.  1).  Piper;  Directors:  li.  J.  Tif- 
fany, J.  H.  Stearns,  J.J.  Papy,  Annis  Menill,D.  S. 
Roberts,  P.  B.  Cornwall,  O.  Livermore. 

Tlie  President,  Secretary,  and  Treasurer,  are  ex 
officio  iiiemlicrs  of  llie  Board  of  Directors,  and  Trus- 
tees of  the  Society.  The  expressed  objects  of  the 
Society  are  to  collect  and  preserve  information  con- 
nected' with  the  early  settlement  and  subsequent 
conquest  of  the  country,  and  to  perpetuate  the  mem- 
ory of  those  whose  sagacity,  energy,  and  enterprise 
induced  them  to  settle  in  the  wilderness  and  become 
the  founders  of  a  new  State.  All  who  were  in  Cal- 
ifornia ^.i^'/o?-  to  the  first  day  of  January,  1850,  are 
eligible  to  membership.  Any  who  have  rendered 
distinguished  or  important  services  to  the  Society, 
the  State,  or  the  United  States,  may  be  admitted  as 
honorary  members.  The  roll  of  the  Society  em- 
braces the  names  of  G70  members.  Regular  meet- 
ings of  the  Society  take  place  on  the  first  Monday 
of  each  month.  Annual  election  of  officers  on  the 
7th  day  of  .July.  The  Anniversary  of  the  Conquest 
of  California,  and  of  tlie  raising  of  the  American 
Flag  on  its  soil.  Annual  Celebration  on  the  9th  of 
September;  the  Anniversary  of  the  Admission  of 
California  into  the  Union.  The  Society  is  possessed 
of  an  excellent  library,  many  curious  and  interest- 
ing relics  of  the  "  Early  Times,"  and  a  cabinet  of 
minerals.  Its  affairs  are  in  an  eminently  flourishing 
condition  ;  its  finances  on  a  sound  basis,  and  numbers 
of  new  candidates  for  membership  being  proposed 
each  month.  The  new  Hall,  erected  on  the  lot  gen- 
erously donated  to  the  Society  by  James  Lick,  Esq., 
is  a  fine  specimen  of  the  Corinthian  order  of  archi- 
tecture. Three  stories  and  basement  in  hight,  and 
forty  by  eighty -four  feet  in  dimensions,  and  is  one 
of  the  most  substantial  buildings  in  the  city.  With 
a  modern  style  French  roof,  and  an  elaborately  yet 
chastely  adorned  front,  forming  one  of  the  most  ele- 
gant and  tasteful,  of  the  many  magniticent  struc- 
tures ornamenting  our  fasliionable  thoroughfare. — 
Tlie  Hall,  which  cost  $-J(),000,  was  built  under  the 
sole  management  of  the  Building  Committee,  Messrs. 
Willard  H.  Farwell,  Peter  Donahue,  Alexander  G. 
Abell,  Samuel  Brannan,  and  B.  O.  Devoe,  Esqs., 
on  whose  ability  and  taste  the  perfectness  of  detail 
reflects  great  c'ledit.  Messrs.  S.  C.  Bugbee  &.  Son, 
architects,  and  John  McFadden  and  A.  C.  Latson, 
contractors.

MECHANICS'  INSTriTTK.— Organized  March 
2*.)th,  J8.').5.  Rooms,  south  wide  California  Street,  be- 
tween Montgomery  and  Kearny.  This  Association 
has  recently  purchased  a  commodious  and  desii-able 
building  on  California  Street,  and  have  dedicated  it 
to  the  j)urposes  of  the  organization.  The  objects  of 
the  Inslitulo,  are  the  establiKhiiieut  of  a  library, 
reading-rooni,  collection  of  a  cabinet,  scientific  appa- 
ratus, works  of  art,  «nd  other  literary  and  scientific 
purposes.  The  Society  has  a  reading-room  well  sup- 
plied with  the  leading  scientific  and  literary  period- 
icals of  the  day,  and  a  valuable  library  containing 
over  Sj.'iOO  volumes.  During  the  year  1858  and  1860, 


this  Institute  presented  to  the  attention  of  the  peo- 
ple of  California  their  second  and  third  annual  exhi- 
bitions, which  were  attended  with  the  most  complete 
success.

MERCANTILE  LIBRARY  ASSOCIATION.— 

Mercantile  Library  Building,  northeast  corner  of 
Montgomerv  and  Bush  streets.  Organized  January 
24th,  1853,  by  the  election  of  D.  S.  Turner,  Presi- 
dent; Joshua  P.  Haven,  Vice  President;  C.  E. 
Bowers,  Treasurer ;  W.  H.  Stevens,  Recording  Sec- 
retary ;  Dr.  Henry  Gibbons,  Corresponding  Secre- 
tary i  and  Messrs.  E.  P.  Flint,  E.  E.  Duuba'r,  D.  H.

eral Review,  for  a  notice  of  this  useful  and  deserv- 
edly popular  Institution.) 

MERCHANTS'  EXCHANGE.— Theodore  E. 
Baugh,  proprietor,  521  Clay  Street,  south  side,  be- 
tween Sanson!  and  Montgomery.  The  Merchants' 
Exchange  was  opened  by  Messrs.  Sweeny  &  Baugh, 
in  March,  1852,  on  Sacramento  Street,  one  square 
south  of  its  present  location,  and  in  September,  1853, 
they  completed  a  line  of  Telegraph  to  Point  Lobos, 
(south  head)  enabling  them  to  report  as  soon  as  they 
could  be  signalized  at  sea,  the  names  of  inward- 
bound  vessels.  The  Telegraph  Line  is  the  pioneer 
on  the  Pacific  coast.  In  July,  1855,  the  Exchange 
was  located  in  its  present  commodious  rooms,  where 
can  be  found  files  of  the  leading  newspapers,  foreign 
"and  domestic.      1 

»

PACIFIC  LYCEUM.— Organized  September, 
1862,  for  the  purposes  of  debate  and  extemporaneous 
speaking.  Meetings  held  every  Saturday  evening 
in  the  Fourth  District  Court  Room.  Officers — Presi-

SOCIAL  LITERARY  SOCIETY,  Y.  M.  C.  A.^ 

Organized  November  3, 1862.  Meets  every  Thurs- 
day evening  in  the  rooms  of  the  Young  Men's  Chris- 
tian Association,  for  the  purpose  of  debate,  literary 
exercise,  and  improvement  in  elocution.  This  Society 
possesses  unusual  advantages  as  a  literary  organiza- 
tion, having  indirectly  connected  with  it  an  exten- 
sive and  well  selected  library,  that  of  the  Yoniig 
Men's  Christian  Association ;  being  supported  by 
that  institution,  and  consequently  no  dues  or  initia- 
tion fees  are  exacted.  There  is  also  sustained  by  the 
Society  a  literary  periodical  called  "  The  Social 
Voice,"  which,  under  the  able  editorship  of  J.  Q. 
Adams,  would  do  honor  to  a  more  pretentious  organ- 
ization. The  debates  are  ably  sustained,  and  the 
various  other  literary  exercises  are  profitable  and 
interesting.  Visitors  and  the  public  generally  are 
welcome  to  attend  and  participate  in  the  exercises  at 
all  times.

cents.  Sub.sciibing  members  are  admitted  on  })ay- 
ment  of  50  cents,  and  a  monthly  assessment  of  ^5 
cents.  There  is  attached  to  this  library,  a  valuable 
collection  of  Manuscript  Letters  of  the  old  Spanish 
Missionaries,  relating  to  the  early  history  of  the 
Missions  of  Upper  and  Lower  C'alifo'.nia,  d.iting 
from  the  middle  of  the  last  century.  The  library 
room  is  open  every  Sunday  afternoon  for  the  recep- 
tion of  visitors  and  persons  desirous  of  becoming 
members,  and  on  Thursday  evenings.  Regular 
monthly  meetings  first   Jlonday  of  each   month. 

Officers — President :  P.  O.  Barry ;  Vice  Presi- 
dent: Wm.  H.  Ash;  Recording  Secretary:  T.  J. 
Gallagher ;  Corresponding  Secretary  :  Johii  P.  Car- 
roll;  Treasurer:  M.  Flood;  Librarian:  P.  Cum- 
mings.

PACIFIC  SAENGERBUND.— This  is  the  name 
of  an  oi-y-aiiization  of  all  the  singing  Clubs  of  Cali- 
fornia, exec))!  the  San  Francisco  Harmonic  and  the 
Teutonic  Maeiuierchor,  and  has  for  its  olyect  the 
cultivation  of  singing  in  general,  to  facilitate  as 
much  as  possible  the  establisment  of  new  singing 
clubs  furnishing  to  them  music  at  a  ('heap  rate,  by 
publishing  in  print  the  best  known  songs,  and  giv- 
ing them  any  information  touching  the  objects  of 
their  organization.  Furthermore,  to  accomplish  any 
kind  of  coniuiission  in  this  line  without  charge, 
when  it  i.s  within  reach  of  the  Board. 

The  association  is  represented  by  a  Board  of  five 
Boardnien,  of  whom  one  is  President,  one  Secreta- 
ry, and  one  Cashier.  The  present  Board  consists 
of — Preside.nt :  E.  Sehnabel ;  Secretary  :  E.  J.  Pfei- 
ffer; Cashier:  J.  C.  Sack;  Boardnien:  J.  Heiz- 
mann and  X.  Huber. 

The  following  Societies  compose  the  Saengerbund : 
Eintracht,  San  Francisco  ;  Turn  Verein,  Stockton ; 
Liederkranz.  Marysville;  Maennerchor,  San  Jos6  ; 
Quartette,  Oroville  ;  Liedertafel,  Yreka;  Gesang- 
verein,  Vallecito  :  Orpheus,  Weaverville  ;  Teutonia, 
Los  Angeles ;  Liederkranz,  Anaheim  ;  Eintracht, 
Stockton ;  Germania,  Victoria,  V.  I. ;  and  Germania, 
Virginia  City.

ahty,  to  improve  healtli,  and  cnltivate  music.  Stated

ciation, a  school  for  boys  from  seven  to  eighteen 
years,  which  now  numbers  95  pupils.  Exercises  for 
the  members,  every  Tuesday  ;  for  boys,  Wednes- 
days and  Siiturdays,  from  8  to  10  o'clock.

THE  GRAND  LODGE  OF  FREE  AND 
ACCEPTED  MASONS  OF  THE  STATE  OF 
CALIFORNIA. — Assembles  annually  at  the  City 
of  San  Fr.incisco.  Its  meetings  heretofore  have 
been  held  on  the  second  Tuesday  in  May,  but  at  the 
last  communication  the  time  of  meeting  was  changed 
imto  the  second  Tuesdaj'  of  October.  Its  officers 
from  Mav,  1863,  to  October,  1864,  are—

THE  GRAND  CHAPTER  OF  ROYAL  ARCH 
MASONS  OF  THE  STATE  OF  CALIFORNIA. 

— Assembles  annually  at  San  Francisco,  on  the 
Thur.;day  next  preceding  the  second  Tuesday  in 
October.  Its  officers  from  May,  1863  to  October, 
lSfi4,  are—

company  has  branch  express  offices  in  all  the  prin-

Idaho  and  Washington  Territories,  and  banking 
offices  at  Sacramento  and  Stockton,  Cal.,  Portland, 
Oregon,  Victoria,  V.  I.,  Virginia  and  Carson,  N.  T., 
connecting  in  their  express  business  with  all  the 
principal  express  companies  in  the  Atlantic  States 
and  Europe.  E.stablished  branch  in  California, 
July  13,  1852.

Hospitals. 

COUNTY  HOSPITAL.— South-west  corner  Fran- 
cisco and  Stockton.  Resident  Physician,  Charles  H. 
Ravmond,  M.D. ;  Visiliug  Surgeon,  F.  A.  Holman, 
M.b. ;  Visiting  Physician,  S.  K.  Gerry,  M.D. ;  M. 
C.  Bateman,  Contractor  tor  Diet,  etc.  Average 
number  of  patients,  290  ;  daily  adniii^sions,  3.  Deaths 
about  •'3  per  cent,  per  annuui.  The  situation  of  the 
building  occupiefl  bv  the  Hospital  is  salubrious  and 
beautiful — on  tlie  sfiore  of  the  Nortli  Beach,  com- 
manding an  extensive  view  of  the  Bay,  immediately 
o])poHiTe  Alcatraces  and  Angel  Islands,  witli  the  vil- 
lage of  Saiicelito  and  the  pi('turci-()ue  head-lands  of 
Miiriu  county  ill  the  di.'tance.  'I'lic  structure  is  of 
brick,  and,  with  the  recent  additions,  capable  of 
accommodating  200  patieuts.  The  present  charge 
on  our  citizens  for  all  purposes  connected  with  the 
care  and  maintenance  of  the  indigent  sick,  is  but 
$.5,000  per  month,  as  compared  with  $f(),143,  the 
average  monthly  expenditure  for  three  years  prior 
to  the  consolidation  of  the  goveriinicnt  of  the  city 
and  county.  An  allowance  of  $(3,000  is  made  for  the 
support  of  a  small  po.x  liosjiital.  In  addition  to  those 
within  the  Hospital,  there  is  an  average  of  500  out- 
side patients  yearly. 


FRENCH  HOSPITAL.— Sustained  by  the  French 
Benevoliiii  Society;  Fifth  and  Sixth.  (See  Benevo- 
lent Associations.) 

GERMAN  HOSPITAL.— Sustained  by  the  Ger- 
man Benevolent  Society  ;  Brannan  and  Third.  (See 
Benevolent  Associations.) 

HOSPITAL  OF  THE  SISTERS  OF  MERCY. 

— Corner  Bryant  and  First.  Conducted  by  the  Sis- 
ters of  Mercy.  Sister  Mary  B.  Russell,  Superior; 
Visiting  Physicians :  Drs.  H.  H.  Toland  and  J  P. 
Whitney  ;  Resident  Physician  :  Dr.  J.  Lee.  The 
Sisters  took  possession  of  this  building  December, 
1861.  The  portion  of  it  now  erected  is  123  feet  on 
Bryant  and  7.5  feet  on  First — four  stories  high.  Cost, 
$100,000.  There  are  private  rooms  and  wards  to 
accommodate  one  hundred  and  eighty  patients.  The 
portion  erected  is  about  one-l^lf  of  the  contemplated 
Hospital. 

ITALIAN  HOSPITAL.— Sustained  by  the  Ital- 
ian Mutual  Benevolent  Society.  (See  Benevolent 
Associations.) 

PACIFIC   CLINICAL   INFIRMARY.— Dr.  L. 

C.  Lane,  658  and  660  Mission  between  Second  and 
Third.  In  this  institution  are  treated  patients  who 
suffer  from  diseases  of  the  eye,  ear,  and  general  sur- 
gical affections.  Surgeon,  Professor  L.  C.  Lane, 
M.D. 

UNITED    STATES    MARINE    HOSPITAL.— 

Rincon  Point,  between  Main  and  Spear.  Organized 
16th  Mai-ch,  1852.  Original  Officers— D.  Jamison, 
Surgeon;  Rev.  O.  Clark,  Suiieriiitendent ;  R.  Mc- 
Millan, Surgeon;  G.  W.  Beach,  Aj  ot'iecary.  Build- 
mg  erected  November,  1853.  O^^cers— Surgeon 
and  Resident  Physician,  John  Hastings.  Daily  ad- 
missions, 3 ;  deaths  per  month,  2 ;  average  number 
of  patieuts,  90.

The  Machine  Shop  possesses  the  greatest  number  and  the  largest  dimensions  of  Tools  in  the  State. 
Tliey  have  Lathes  to  turn  nine  feet  in  diameter  and  thirty  feet  long.  Tlieir  other  facilities  for 
executing  work  rapidly  and  efficiently  are  unsurpassed.  Upwards  of  300  Steam  Engines,  made 
at  their  own  Works,  are  now  running  in  this  State  and  Oregon,  in  Steamboats,  Quartz  Mills,  Saw 
and  Flouring  Mills. 

Their  Boiler  Works  have  turned  out  upwards  of  600  Steam  Boilers  of  all  kinds. 

Quartz  Mills,  Flour  Mills,  Hydraulic  and  other  Presses,  Hoisting  Machines, 
Gearing  PuUies,  G-udgeons,  Boxes,  Hangers,  Etc.  Etc.,  in  Great  Variety. 

Warranted  to  be  made  of  the  very  hardest  aud  toughest  Iron.

Particular  attention  given  to  casting  Rudder  Sraces,  and  Ship  Work  in  general. 

Removed  from  Oregon  Street,  between  Front  and  Davis.

Oroville,  Butte  County,  February,  1861. 
Messrs.  A.  S.  Hallidie  &  Co.,  Wire  Rope  Manfs:  Gents:—!  have  thoroughly  tested  the  Wire  Rope  you  piit  on  my 
FeiTy  and  to  mv  entire  satisfaction.  After  the  wear  and  tear  of  nearly  two  seasons,  I  judge  it  to  be  as  good  as  when  put 
up.  I  run  the  Ferry  at  all  stages  of  -water,  when  others  are  compelled  to  stand  still.  On  one  occasion,  b.y  a  sudden  rise 
of  the  river,  an  immense  boom,  used  for  collecting  saw  logs  and  an  accumulation  of  logs,  became  fastened  on  the  Wire 
Rope,  carrying  away  the  fastenings  on  one  .side,  but  the  rope  remained  perfect.  We  use  soft  brass  sheaves,  and  the  boat 
travels  across  very  smoothly.  I  can  strongly  recommend  the  use  of  the  Wire  Kope  for  Ferry  purposes— being  satisfied 
that  it  is  cheaper,  safer,  and  more  easily  managed. 

H.  B.  LATHROP. 

American  Bar,  (Near  Michigan  Bluff)  Placer  County,  March  10,  1861. 
Messrs.  A.  .'t.  Hallidie  &  Co.— Gents  :  we  have  used  one  of  your  2  1-2  inch  circumference  Patent  Wire  Ropes,  1,200 
feet  long,  for  twenty-seven  months,  constantly  winding  over  a  capstan  38-inch  di.imeter,  and  lowering  rock  to  our  mill. 
It  has  lasted  as  long  as  ten  Manila  Hopes,  working  in  the  same  place  under  the  same  circumstances;  each  rope  of  equal 
cost  with  your  Wire  Rope.  We  used  Manila  Rope  the  first  year,  but  would  not  now  take  it  as  a  gift,  after  testing  your 
Patent  Wire  Rope. 

Yours  truly,  Bat  State  Quartz  Mining  Co.,    Per  JAMES  H.  BERRY. 

N.  B.— The  above  Company  has  a  double  track  laid  on  the  hill  side  following  its  undulations,  but  having  a  general 
angle  of  about  50".    The  Wire  Rope  is  exposed  to  the  fullest  action  of  the  weather. 

HoKSE  Shoe  Bar,  Middle  Fork  American  River,  May,  1860. 
Messrs.  A.  S.  Hallidie  ife  Co.— G'en^s;— Our  Derricks,  worked  by  overshot  water  wheels,  are  rigged  with  your  Patent 
Rope  Guys.  Tliev  are  better  and  clieapcr  than  any  other  kind  of  rope.  AVitli  them  we  can  keep  our  masts  in  position,  as 
they  are  not  coistantly  strctchmg  and  shrinknig.    Once  set  up  they  are  no  further  trouble.     We  can  strongly  recom- 
mend them.    No  Derrick  can  be  worked  to  advantage  without  Wire  Rope  Guys.  We  remain,  etc. 

[Signed,]  GET  UP  AND  GET  CO.,  Horso  Shoe  Bar,  Per  GEORGE  LANGDON,  Manager. 

UXIOX  MINING  CO.,  Per  DAVID  MEANS,  Manager. 
AMERICAN  B.\U  CO.,  Per  J.  H.  CL.\NCY,  Manager.

LITTLE  PLEASANT  BAR  CO.,  Per  DONELLAN  &  PAGON, 
BOSTON  BAR  CO.,  Per  i.  ROACH.  And  numerous  other  Companies. 

KKf  '  CIRCULARS,  with  scale  of  weights,  sizes,  strengths,  and  list  of  prices  annexed,  will  be  forwarded  to  those

[Cr"  JOSEPH  McGregor  begs  to  announce  to  Merchants,  Captains  of  Ves- 
sels, and  the  public  generally,  that  he  possesses  unequalled  facilities  for  the  ac- 
curate repairing  of  Ciirono'meteks  and  Watches,  on  more  reasonable  terms 
than  those  generally  charged.  Chronometers  and  Watches  are  often  in  this 
country  entrusted  to  incompetent  workmen.  J.  McG.  is  prepared  to  readjust  and 
repair,  in  first  rate  style,  all  Chronometers  and  fine  Watches  put  into  his  hands. 

FOR  SALE. — Chronometers  by  the  most  eminent  makers;  also,  Sextants 
and  Nautical  Instruments  of  all  kinds;  or  lie  will  accurately  repair  and  adjust 
them.  Best  Nautical  Charts  for  all  parts  of  the  world.  Give  mc  a  trial  and 
judge  by  the  result.    Charges  moderate.

HUNT'S  IMPROVED 


Patented  August  19th,  1862. 

The  cheapest  and  best  ever  offered  for  sale;  is 

easily  reguhited  ;  works  well  in  light  winds. 
A  large  number  of  these  celebrated  Windmills  have 
been  set  up  this  year,  and  have  given  per- 
fect satisfaction  to  all  concerned. 


Round  and  Square  Water  Tanks 


Made  to  Order. 


Endless  Chain  self-regulating  Horse-Power. 

These  Horse-Powers  are  regulated  by  a  Governor, 
and  are  suited  for  use  in  all  cases  where  a  small 
power  is  wanted  to  run  a  Lathe  for  turning  Wood, 
Iron  or  Brass — for  running  a  Scroll  Saw,  or  small 
Circular  Saw,  or  Pumping  Water — and  are  war- 
ranted to  run  as  steadily  as  a  Steam  Engine. 

Rights  in  the  above  patents  can  be  had  by  apply- 
ing to  E.  0.  Hunt,  at  the  Windmill  Factory,  San 
Francisco.

HAREISON'S    EGG 


This  pump  is  designed  for  throwing  hirgc  quantities  of  water,  eitlier  as  a  wrecking  pump,  a 
mining  pnnip,  or  for  irrigation.  Its  principal  advantages  are  that  it  is  light  and  compact,  very 
durable  and  not  at  all  liable  to  cliokc  or  get  out  of  order.  It  has  no  valves,  and  no  packing.  It 
is  a  suction  and  force  pump,  and  lias  sucked  tlic  water  up  over  27i  feet. 

It  can  be  run  fast  or  slow,  and  according  to  its  speed  is  the  qnantity  of  water  discharged. 

All  sizes,  capable  of  throwing  from  100  to  .5,000  gallons  per  minute,  for  sale  by

HUCKS  8l  IiAIKEBESRT'S 


C  El  H.  EB  PI -A- T  E  ID 


I^A-TET-TT 


THIS  ErrRAOUDINARY  LUBRICATING  COMPOUND 

Is   procared   by   chemical   conihiiiation    of  suitable   oily   substances,  purified  by  distillation,  and 

freed  from  tlie  resinous  or  pitchy  matter  which  attaciies  to  all  oils,  more  or  less,  in  their  natural  or 
unrefined  state. 

In  operation,  the  PATENT  GREASE  works  free  from  Coomb,  or  Gum  ; 

Friction  by  keeping  the  heaviest  bearings  in  a  soft  oily  state  to  the  last ;  and,  as  its  consistency  is 
not  altered  by  exposure  to  the  hottest  sun  or  coldest  frost,  (its  liquifying  point  being  200  degrees,) 
it  follows  that,  on  axles  which  have  a  tendency  to  become  hot  from  too  heavy  abrasion,  etc.,  the 
anti-friction,  will  adhere  to  and  keep  them  cool,  when  other  substances  would  run  off  and  become 
dry ;  thus  the  evil  known  as 


a 


]e^X3E=M]NrC3-    OJEn*   "WHESESIlji 


?!» 


is  by  its  use  effectually  prevented. 

The  proprietors  will  guarantee  one  application  of  their  PATENT  GREASE  to  carry  the 
heaviest  loaded  team  from  300  to  500  miles  without  requiring  to  be  greased  on  the  road. 

(B^^N.  B.— We  respectfully  caution  the  friends  to  ask  for  HUCKS  &  LAilBEKT'S  AXLE-GREASE,  as 
there  are  several  spurious  imitations  in  the  maiket,  and  see  that  the  trade  mark,  H  &:  Li  is  on  the  red  cover 
of  the  package.

OPPOSITE  THE  PACIFIC  MAIL  STEAMSHIP  COMPANY'S  OFFICE, 


Established  in  1854,  for  the  Permanent  Cure  of  all  Private  and  Chronic  Diseases, 
and  for  the  suppression  of  Quackery. 


Attending  and  Resident  Physician— L.  J.  CZAPKAY,  M.  D. 

Late  in  the  Hungarian  Revolutionary  War,  Chief  Physician  to  the  20Lh  Regi- 
ment of  Honveds,  Chief  Surgeon  of  the  Military  Hospital  of  Pesth,  Hun- 
gary, late  Lecturer  on  Diseases  of  Genito-Urinary  Organs,  and  Diseases 
of  Women  and  Children,  and  Honorary  member  of  the 
Philadelphia  College  of  Medicine,  Etc. 


Particular  attention  paid  to  the  treatment  of  Diseases  peculiar  to  Women  snd  Children.

fby  letter  or  otherwise)  FREE.  Address 

Dr.  L.  J.  CZAPKAY,  San  Francisco. 


Si^erma^torrlxoeet, 

Or  local  weakness,  nervous  deliility,  low  spirits,  lassitude,  weakness  of  the  limbs  and  back,  indispo- 
sition and  incapability  for  labor  and  study,  dullness  of  apprehension,  loss  of  memory,  aversion  to 
society,  love  of  solitude,  timidity,  self-distrust,  dizziness,  headache,  involuntary  discharges,  pains  in 
the  side,  aff'.'ctions  of  the  eye,  pimples  on  the  face,  sexual  or  other  infirmities  in  man,  are  cured  by 
the  justly  celebrated  physician  and  surgeon,  L.  J.  CZAPKAY.  His  method  of  curing  diseases  is 
new,  (unknown  to  others,)  and  hence  the  great  success.     All  consultations,  by  letter  or  otherwise. 

Free.  [T^ Address,  L.  J.  CZAPKAY,  M.  D.,  San  Francisco.

Patients  resklinR  in  any  part  of  the  State,  however  distant,  who  may  desire  the  opinion  and  advice  of  DR.  CZAPKAY, 
on  their  respective  cases,  and  who  thinli  proiier  to  submit  a  written  statement  cif  such,  in  prclerence  U<  hol.iinK  a  per- 
sonal interview,  are  respectfullv  assured  that  their  communications  will  be  held  most  sacred.  DK.  CZAl  KAY  takes 
this  cpportuiiity  of  observing  that  all  lett«T3  are  only  opened  and  replied  to  by  himself,  and  the  latter  as  promptly  as 
possible.  If  the  case  be  fully  and  candidly  described,  personal  communication  will  be  supersede>1,  hh  instructions  for 
diet,  regimen,  and  the  general  treatment  of  the  caes  itself,  (including  the  remedies)  ■!% ill  be  forwarded  without  delay, 
and  in  such  a  manner  as  to  convey  no  idea  of  the  purport  of  the  letter  or  parcel  so  transmitted.  Permanent  cure  guar- 
anteed, or  no  pay.    Consultation  Gratis.

(At  the  IIARMONIA  SCHOOL-HOUSE,  formerly  German  Lutheran  Church.) 

SUTTER  STREET,  SECOND  HOUSE  FROM  STOCKTON  ST. 


UNDER  THE   DIRECTION   OF 

Dr.  JULIUS  ECKM  AN  (l;R.  Z  AHN,  M.  R. 


This  School  is  divided  into  two  branches,  the  DAY-SCHOOL  and  the  PRI- 
MARY SCHOOL.  The  former  is  managed  similar  to  the  Public  Schools  and  the 
latter,  under  the  management  of  Ladies,  aims  especially  at  the  Moral  Training  of  the 
Pupils.  In  both  Departments  especial  attention  is  paid  to  the  study  of  the  German 
Language,  and  most  branches  are  taught  by  the  medium  of  that  Language.

675 


DOUBLE-THREAD  LOCK-STITCH 


From  which  all  others  (having  any  utility)  derive  their  vitality.  Invented  in  1848,  improred 
from  time  to  time  and  fully  perfected  in  1862. 

On  the  Howe  Machines  coarser  thread  may  be  used  on  the  under  spool  than  that  used  above, 
thereby  giving  greater  strength  of  seam  than  can  be  made  on  other  first  class  kinds,  making  the 
stitch  alike  on  both  sides  of  the  fabric.  They  stand  pre-eminently  above  all  others,  both  for  Fam- 
ily and  Manufiicturing  purposes. 

Price  of  the  Letter  A,  Family,  with  Rolling  Presser,  Adjustable  Hemmer,  Braider,  Binder,  and 
the  ordinary  Fixtures,  $G0 — formerly  sold  at  $80.  Letter  A  Pearl  Finish  and  Capped,  $.75,  formerly 
$100;  Letter  B,  Manufacturing,  $75,  formerlv  $100.  Letter  C,  heavy  Manufacturing,  THE  UN- 
RIVALED OF  THIS  AGE,  for  Harness  Making,  Upholstery,  Carriage  Trimming,  Boot  and 
Shoe  Work,  Heavy  Clothing,  $85,  formerlv  $115.  Letter  D,  Cylinder  ( more  especially  for  Boot 
Work  )  $115,  formerly  $150.     Letter  E,  Large  Cylinder,  $140,  formerly  $175. 

The  B  and  C  Machines  will  not  only  sew  from  Medium  to  heavy  Leather  and  Cloth — their  spe- 
cialty— but  execute  beautifully  and  thoroughly,  to  an  astonishing  degree,  in  every  grade  of  Sewing 
down  to  the  finest  gauze,  and  are  being  sold  twenty-five  dollars  cheaper  than  those  of  other  manu- 
factures of  same  cost  and  less  capacity.

The  Sillier  Sfanbarb  or  Manixfadming  Sewing  Machines, 

FOR  GENERAL  MANUFACTURING  PURPOSES, 

Are  universally  and  justly  acknowledged  unrivaled,  and  are  used  in  all  the  great 
manufacturing  establishments  of  the  United  States  and  Europe,  to  the  almost  total 
exclusion  of  all  other  machines.  The  correct  and  superior  Mechanical  principles  of 
these  machines,  is  the  secret  of  their  being  beyond  competition. 

Onr  Letter*  -A.,  Transverse  Shixttle, 


IfEj 


Is  fast  gaining  a  world-wide  reputation. 


It  is,  beyond  doubt,  the  best  and  cheapest  of  all  Family  Sewing  Machines  yet  offered  to  the  pub- 
lic. No  other  Family  Sewing  Machine  has  so  many  useful  appliances  for  Hemming,  Binding,  Fell- 
ing, Tucking,  Gathering,  Gauging,  Braiding,  Embroidering,  Cording,  and  so  forth.  No  other 
Family  Sewing  Machine  has  so  much  capacity  for  a  great  variety  of  work.  It  will  sew  all  kinds 
of  cloth,  and  with  all  kinds  of  thread.  Great  and  recent  improvements  make  our  Family  Sewing 
Machine  most  reliable,  nnd  most  durable,  and  most  certain  in  action  at  all  rates  of  speed.  It  makes 
the  interlocked  stitch,  which  is  the  best  stitch  known.  Any  one,  even  of  the  most  ordinary  capacity, 
can  see  at  a  glance  how  to  use  the  Letter  A  Family  Sewing  Machine.  Our  Family  Sewing  Macliines 
arc  finished  in  chaste  and  ex(iuisite  style.  The  Folding  Case  of  the  Family  Machine  is  a  piece  of 
cunning  workmanship  of  the  most  useful  kind.  It  protects  the  machine  when  not  in  use,  and  when 
about  to  be  operated  may  be  opened  as  a  spacious  and  substantial  table  to  sustain  the  work.  It  is 
absolutely  necessary  to  see  the  Fan\ily  Machine  in  operation,  so  as  to  judge  of  its  great  capacity 
and  beauty.  It  is  fast  becoming  as  popular  for  fiimily  sewing  as  our  Manufacturing  machines  are 
for  manufacturing  purposes.

t.  Ipatiits'  €&\\qt, 

Market  Street,  between  Fourth  and  Fifth  Streets, 


»» > 


This  Institution,  conducted  by  the  Fathers  of  the  Soci- 
ety of  Jesus,  was  opened  for  the  reception  of  Students  on 
the  15th  of  October,  1855.  On  the  30th  of  April,  1859, 
it  was  incorporated  and  empowered  to  confer  degrees  and 
academical  honors  in  all  the  learned  professions,  and  to 
exercise  all  the  rights  and  privileges  common  to  any  other 
literary  institution  in  the  United  States. 

THE  DESIGN  OF  THIS  INSTITUflON  IS  TO  GIVE  A  THOROUGH 

English,  Classical,  Matiiematical  and  Philosophical 

EDncj^Tio: 


It  is  inteiiclecl  for  cla.y  l!!»cliolar'SBi  only. 

The  Course  of  Studies  embraces  the  Greek,  Latin  and  English  Languages, 

Poetry,  Rhetoric,  Elocution,  History,  Geography,  Arithmetic,  Book- 

Keeping,  Mathematics,  Chemistry,  Mental,  Moral  and  Natural 

Philosophy.    The  study  of  Modern  Languages  is  optional. 

Besides  the  Classical,  there  is  a  Preparatory  Department  for  the  younger  students. 
Its  object  is  to  qualify  the  pupils  for  the  higher  studies. 

This  Institution,  provided  with  a  full  staff  of  Professors,  presents  considerable  ad- 
vantages for  the  mental  and  moral  training  of  the  Students. 

A  Complete  Philosophical  Apparatus  has  been  ordered  from  Paris. 

The  Laboratory  contains  over  Ttvo  Hundred  and  Fifty  Pure  Chemicals^  and  all 

that  is  necessary  for  the  most  complicated  manipulations  and  analysis. 

The  College  has,  moreover,  a  complete  Photographic  Gallery. 

A  Telegraphic  Apparatus  ha-  also  biieu  provided,  wliich,  through  the  kindness  of 
the  California  State  Telegraph  Company,  connects  St.  Ignatius'  College  with  Santa 
Clara  College,  Santa  Clara  County. 

TERMS    PER    MONTH  : 

Tuition  in  tlio  Grammar  Department, S5  00 

do  do       Higher  Department 8  00 

do  do       Preparatory^  Department 3  00

ST.  MARY'S  COUfiCE 

THE  OBJECT  OF  THIS  INSTITUTION  IS  TO  IMPART 

A  SOUND  PRACTICAL  EDUCATION 

A.T    THE 

LOWEST  POSSIBLE  COST, 
THEREBY  PLACING  ITS  ADVANTAGES  WITHIN  REACH  OF  ALL

So  that  boys,  whether  destined  for  Mechanical,  Commercial  or  Professional  pur- 
suits, can  select  such  studies  as  will  best  fit  them  for  future  avocations.

with  the  month  in  which  they  enter.
